Balanced Tomato Dataset/Tomato_Yellow_Le.description: A serious viral disease causing severe stunting, upward cupping, and yellowing of young leaves. Infected plants produce little or no marketable fruit. Spread exclusively by the Whitefly vector (Bemisia tabaci). No cure exists.

organic_solution.strategy: Strict sanitation and physical exclusion. Management is 100% focused on eliminating the whitefly vector and immediately destroying infected plants.

products.name: Insecticidal Soap / Neem Oil
products.details: Apply weekly for whitefly control. Good coverage is essential.

products.name: Fine Netting (40-50 mesh)
products.details: Use fine netting to exclude whiteflies in protected structures.

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires the rotation of systemic neonicotinoids and insect growth regulators (IGRs) to manage resistance development in whitefly populations.

products.name: Imidacloprid (e.g., Confidor)
products.details: Apply a neonicotinoid (Group 4A) as a soil drench or foliar spray.

products.name: Spiromesifen (e.g., OZIL)
products.details: Alternate with a different mode of action, Group 23 insecticide.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Tomato_Yellow_Le.pathogen_timeline: Symptoms develop slowly (up to 3 weeks) after infection, but once established, the whitefly vector can cause rapid, high-level spread across the field.
prevention_tips: Use certified virus-free seedlings or grafts.
Monitor fields with yellow sticky traps to detect whitefly presence early.
Avoid planting new tomato crops near old, abandoned tomato or pepper fields.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Tomato_mosaic_vi.description: A highly stable virus causing mottling, dark and light green patterns, 'fern leaf' deformation, and overall stunting. Spread primarily mechanically through contact (hands, tools, clothing).

organic_solution.strategy: Strict adherence to hygiene. There is no biological cure; immediate removal and sterilization are paramount.

products.name: Sanitation (Bleach Solution)
products.details: Sanitize tools and hands with a 10% bleach solution.

chemical_solution.strategy: No chemical treatment is effective against the virus itself. Focus entirely on prevention and sanitation protocols.

products.name: Surface Disinfectants
products.details: Use approved disinfectants (e.g., quaternary ammonium) to clean structures.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Tomato_mosaic_vi.pathogen_timeline: No cure. Spread is mechanical (tools/hands). The virus is highly stable and can survive on surfaces and debris for long periods (years), posing a high risk of propagation through poor field hygiene.
prevention_tips: Avoid smoking or using tobacco products near the crop.
Remove and destroy any suspicious plants immediately.
Wash hands thoroughly after handling plants.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Target_Spot.description: A serious fungal disease favored by high humidity and temperature, causing distinct dark, target-like lesions on leaves (often with concentric rings) and deep, scabby spots on fruit. Thrives in warm, humid conditions.

organic_solution.strategy: Focus on environmental control (ventilation) and preventative copper-based treatments. Sanitation is vital.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide (e.g., Kocide)
products.details: Apply as a protective barrier (FRAC M1).

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires effective broad-spectrum fungicides. Rotate contact protectants (Group M) with high-efficacy systemics (Group 11 or 3).

products.name: Mancozeb
products.details: Apply as a broad-spectrum contact fungicide (FRAC M03).

products.name: Azoxystrobin (e.g., Ortiva 250 SC)
products.details: Alternate with a systemic QoI fungicide (FRAC 11).

products.name: Difenoconazole (e.g., Score 250 EC)
products.details: Alternate with a systemic DMI fungicide (FRAC 3) for curative action.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Target_Spot.pathogen_timeline: Infection requires 16-44 hours of leaf wetness. If established, numerous lesions form, causing tissue collapse and potential plant death, making timely application critical for protecting yield.
prevention_tips: Use drip irrigation to minimize leaf wetness.
Practice crop rotation.
Control weeds, as they can act as alternate hosts.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Spider_mites Two.description: Tiny arachnid pests that suck sap from the leaf underside, causing fine white stippling on the upper surface, bronzing, and defoliation. Produces webbing in severe infestations and thrives in hot, dry conditions.

organic_solution.strategy: Utilize biological control (predators) and specific botanical or biological miticides, ensuring excellent coverage of the leaf underside.

products.name: Predatory Mites (Phytoseiulus persimilis)
products.details: Biological control agent. Release predatory mites.

products.name: Horticultural Oil (e.g., Sunspray)
products.details: Apply for contact kill, ensuring good coverage of leaf underside.

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires specialized miticides (acaricides). Resistance management is critical; rotate strictly between IRAC Groups.

products.name: Abamectin (e.g., Abamec 1.8 EC)
products.details: Highly effective miticide (IRAC Group 6).

products.name: Spiromesifen (e.g., OZIL)
products.details: Rotate with Group 23, targets eggs and immature stages.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Spider_mites Two.pathogen_timeline: Extremely rapid lifecycle, completing in approximately 7 days at high temperatures (30°C). Population knockdown and mortality occur within 3–4 days after effective chemical application.
prevention_tips: Maintain adequate irrigation; water-stressed plants are more susceptible.
Avoid broad-spectrum insecticides, which can kill natural mite predators.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Septoria_leaf_sp.description: A widespread fungal disease starting on lower leaves, characterized by small, circular spots with a gray or tan center and a dark border ('frog-eye' appearance). Leads to severe defoliation and yield loss.

organic_solution.strategy: Sanitation and preventative barrier sprays. Remove infected lower leaves immediately.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide
products.details: Apply as a preventative barrier spray (FRAC M1).

products.name: Mulch
products.details: Mulch the soil surface to prevent spores splashing onto lower leaves.

chemical_solution.strategy: Follow the same rotational protocol as Early Blight, prioritizing protectants early in the season.

products.name: Mancozeb
products.details: Apply protectant every 7-10 days (FRAC M03).

products.name: Difenoconazole (e.g., Score 250 EC)
products.details: Alternate with a systemic DMI fungicide (FRAC 3) for curative control.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Septoria_leaf_sp.pathogen_timeline: Disease is favored by leaf wetness. Once symptoms appear, control is difficult. Fungicides must be applied regularly (preventatively/early) to halt the upward progression and protect new foliage, as existing lesions cannot be cured.
prevention_tips: Avoid overhead irrigation.
Maintain a 3-year crop rotation cycle.
Disinfect stakes and cages between seasons.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/powdery_mildew.description: Fungal growth appearing as white, powdery patches, usually on the upper surface of leaves. Common in high-humidity, sheltered environments (greenhouses) where airflow is poor.

organic_solution.strategy: Easily managed with environmental controls and sulfur-based or potassium bicarbonate sprays.

products.name: Wettable Sulphur
products.details: Apply elemental sulfur dust or wettable sulfur spray (FRAC M02).

products.name: Potassium Bicarbonate
products.details: Use a solution as a contact fungicide.

chemical_solution.strategy: Utilize sulfur and targeted systemic fungicides. Caution: Do not use sulfur when temperatures exceed 30°C to avoid phytotoxicity.

products.name: Difenoconazole (e.g., Score 250 EC)
products.details: Apply a DMI fungicide (FRAC 3).

products.name: Azoxystrobin (e.g., Ortiva 250 SC)
products.details: Alternate with a systemic QoI fungicide (FRAC 11).

Balanced Tomato Dataset/powdery_mildew.pathogen_timeline: Spreads rapidly, particularly in sheltered areas with poor airflow. Effective control with fungicides or organic sprays can stop new infections, typically requiring repeated application (e.g., weekly) to manage existing growth and protect new foliage.
prevention_tips: Ensure maximum ventilation in greenhouses.
Prune plants to increase air circulation.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Leaf_Mold.description: A fungal disease exclusive to high-humidity situations (often greenhouses). Causes yellow spots on the upper leaf surface with corresponding olive-brown/purple velvety mold patches on the underside.

organic_solution.strategy: Primary focus is on ventilation and humidity reduction, as the pathogen cannot tolerate dry conditions.

products.name: Ventilation
products.details: Increase heating and ventilation to lower relative humidity below 85%.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide
products.details: Apply copper-based protectant sprays (FRAC M1).

chemical_solution.strategy: Use preventative contact fungicides and target systemics only if necessary.

products.name: Chlorothalonil (e.g., Bravo 720 SC)
products.details: Apply a protectant fungicide (FRAC M05).

products.name: Azoxystrobin (e.g., Ortiva 250 SC)
products.details: In severe cases, alternate with a systemic QoI fungicide (FRAC 11).

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Leaf_Mold.pathogen_timeline: Requires high humidity (>85%). New spore generations develop in 10-12 days, leading to rapid spread within the canopy unless ventilation is immediately improved to dry foliage and inhibit sporulation.
prevention_tips: Avoid watering late in the day.
Prune densely growing plants to allow air penetration.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Late_blight.description: The most destructive Oomycete disease, causing dark, water-soaked lesions that rapidly spread across leaves and stems. Often exhibits a white, fuzzy mold on the underside of leaves. Capable of destroying a crop in days.

organic_solution.strategy: Aggressive removal of infected material and use of high-concentration copper products. Must be applied preventatively under high-risk (wet/cool) conditions.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide
products.details: Apply at short intervals (4-5 days) (FRAC M1).

products.name: Sanitation
products.details: IMMEDIATELY remove and destroy all infected plant debris.

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires immediate, tight-interval (5-day) application using highly effective contact-systemic rotations to achieve curative action and prevent spore production.

products.name: Cymoxanil + Mancozeb (e.g., Curzate Pro)
products.details: Rotate immediately with a blend product (FRAC 27 + M03) for curative knockdown.

products.name: Chlorothalonil (e.g., Bravo 720 SC)
products.details: Use in alternation with specialized Oomycete fungicides (FRAC M05).

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Late_blight.pathogen_timeline: Rapidly spreading, destructive pathogen capable of plant collapse in days. Infection occurs within ~10 hours under ideal humid conditions (15.5°–25.5°C). Curative treatment requires immediate, tight-interval (5-day) application of specialized fungicides.
prevention_tips: Avoid planting tomatoes near potatoes, which are also hosts.
Use resistant tomato varieties.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Early_blight.description: A common fungal disease causing large, dark brown spots, typically on older foliage, displaying characteristic concentric rings (bullseye). Can lead to extensive defoliation and fruit collar rot.

organic_solution.strategy: Sanitation (removing lower infected leaves) and protective Copper barrier sprays are the primary defense.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide
products.details: Apply Copper-based fungicides (FRAC M1).

products.name: Compost / Bio-fertilizers
products.details: Maintain soil health to boost plant immunity.

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires a strong rotation between protectant and highly effective systemic fungicides (Groups 3 and 11) to manage established infections.

products.name: Mancozeb
products.details: Apply as a contact protectant (FRAC M03).

products.name: Azoxystrobin + Difenoconazole (e.g., ZODIO)
products.details: Alternate with a combined systemic product (FRAC 11 + 3) for robust curative action.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Early_blight.pathogen_timeline: Polycyclic disease; repeating cycles of infection can spread rapidly under moist, warm conditions (up to 32°C). Management requires systemic/contact fungicides to protect new growth and prevent upward progression from the base of the plant.
prevention_tips: Use certified disease-free seeds.
Mulch soil surface to prevent spore splash.
Prune lower leaves that touch the soil.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Bacterial_spot.description: A destructive bacterial infection causing small, angular, greasy spots on leaves and raised, scabby, dark lesions on fruit. Favored by warm, wet conditions; spread rapidly by rain and handling.

organic_solution.strategy: Strict sanitation and proactive use of Copper compounds, which act as surface bactericides.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide/Oxychloride
products.details: Apply Copper products (FRAC M1) every 7 days.

products.name: Bacillus amyloliquefaciens
products.details: Use biological control products as a preventative measure.

chemical_solution.strategy: The standard treatment is a combination or tight rotation of a Copper bactericide and Mancozeb to enhance control and manage resistance.

products.name: Copper + Mancozeb Tank Mix
products.details: Apply a tank mix of Copper Hydroxide/Sulfate (M1) and Mancozeb (M03).

products.name: Kasugamycin
products.details: In rotation, apply an approved antibiotic (FRAC 24) to manage resistance risk.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/Bacterial_spot.pathogen_timeline: Symptoms develop rapidly (within 5 days) under optimal conditions. No systemic cure exists; copper/mancozeb tank mixes suppress spread to healthy tissue. Focus must be on containment and sanitation to protect marketable fruit.
prevention_tips: Use hot-water treated or certified disease-free seed.
Avoid working in the field when plants are wet.
Prune only when dry and sanitize tools afterward.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/healthy.description: The plant exhibits strong vigor, uniform growth, deep green color, and high yield potential, demonstrating successful preventative measures and adequate nutrition.

organic_solution.strategy: Maintain soil fertility and structure. Focus on preventative bio-control applications to suppress endemic pathogens before they establish.

products.name: Microbial Inoculants (Trichoderma)
products.details: Apply as preventative soil drenches.

products.name: Compost Tea
products.details: Use to promote beneficial microbial activity.

chemical_solution.strategy: Implement a balanced fertigation program tailored to the tomato growth stage (vegetative, flowering, fruiting) and monitor soil pH/nutrient levels.

products.name: Balanced NPK Fertilizer (e.g., 20-20-20)
products.details: Use a complete NPK fertilizer program.

products.name: Calcium/Boron Foliar Spray
products.details: Apply during fruiting stage to prevent blossom end rot.

Balanced Tomato Dataset/healthy.pathogen_timeline: N/A. Focus is on continuous preventative nutritional and cultural management to maintain optimal health and resilience, ensuring that plant stress does not invite opportunistic pathogens.
prevention_tips: Implement a strong integrated pest management (IPM) plan.
Rotate crops to break disease cycles.
Regularly inspect the field (scouting) to detect issues before they reach 5% incidence.

Balanced Pumpkin Dataset/Powdery_Mildew.description: A common fungal disease (Erysiphe cichoracearum/Podosphaera xanthii) appearing as white, powdery spots on the upper and lower leaf surfaces. Reduces photosynthesis and yield significantly.
Balanced Pumpkin Dataset/Powdery_Mildew.timeline_metric: PROMPT (3-5 Days) - Treat quickly upon initial sighting to prevent rapid defoliation.

organic_solution.strategy: Easily treatable. Rotation between contact organics (milk/baking soda) and bio-fungicides is advised.

products.name: Wettable Sulphur
products.details: Contact protectant (FRAC M2); caution required above 30°C.

products.name: Biological Fungicide (e.g., Bacillus subtilis)
products.details: Prevents spore germination and suppresses disease progression.

chemical_solution.strategy: Apply targeted fungicides. Rotate strictly between multi-site protective Sulphur (M2) and systemic Triazoles (Group 3) to prevent resistance.

products.name: Difenoconazole (e.g., Score 250 EC)
products.details: Systemic DMI/Triazole fungicide (FRAC 3). Highly curative.

products.name: Elemental Sulphur
products.details: Multi-site contact protectant (FRAC M2) used in rotation.

prevention_tips: Ensure good air circulation within the canopy.
Plant resistant varieties.
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization.

Balanced Pumpkin Dataset/Mosaic_Disease.disease_name: Mosaic Disease (e.g., Zucchini Yellow Mosaic Virus - ZYMV)
Balanced Pumpkin Dataset/Mosaic_Disease.description: A viral disease causing severe stunting, leaf deformation, yellow mosaic patterns, and malformed fruit. Spread rapidly by insect vectors, primarily aphids. No chemical cure exists.
Balanced Pumpkin Dataset/Mosaic_Disease.timeline_metric: PREVENTATIVE/MONITORING - Focus exclusively on vector control and sanitation; symptoms appear after inoculation.

organic_solution.strategy: Vector control and physical barriers are the only recourse once the virus is established in the field.

products.name: Horticultural Oil / Insecticidal Soap
products.details: Physical control agent to suppress aphid populations.

products.name: Fine Netting (Row Covers)
products.details: Physical exclusion barrier against aphid vectors.

chemical_solution.strategy: Target the aphid vectors immediately using modern chemistry (IRAC 29) to mitigate local resistance, especially in high-population scenarios.

products.name: Flonicamid (e.g., Strangle)
products.details: Specific aphicide (IRAC 29). Excellent knockdown control.

prevention_tips: Use certified virus-free seedlings.
Immediately remove and destroy (do not compost) any plant showing mosaic symptoms.
Practice early-season vector control and scouting.

Balanced Pumpkin Dataset/Healthy_Leaf.description: The plant exhibits strong vigor, uniform growth, and high yield potential, demonstrating successful preventative measures and adequate nutrition.

organic_solution.strategy: Focus on continuous preventative nutritional and cultural management to maintain optimal health.

products.name: Compost Tea / Bio-stimulant
products.details: Foliar or soil application to enhance plant immunity and vitality.

products.name: Seaweed Extract
products.details: Source of micronutrients and phytohormones to reduce plant stress.

chemical_solution.strategy: Implement a balanced fertigation program, tailored to the cucurbit growth stage (vegetative, flowering, fruiting).

products.name: Balanced NPK Fertilizer
products.details: Water-soluble fertilizer tailored for cucurbit stages.

products.name: Calcium Nitrate
products.details: Crucial for fruit development and preventing blossom end rot.

prevention_tips: Practice crop rotation (at least 3 years) with non-cucurbit crops.
Maintain soil pH between 6.0 and 7.0 for optimal nutrient uptake.
Avoid excessive overhead watering to minimize favorable conditions for fungal diseases.

Balanced Pumpkin Dataset/Downy_Mildew.description: Caused by the Oomycete Pseudoperonospora cubensis. Highly aggressive, causes angular, water-soaked, yellow lesions on leaves, often leading to rapid defoliation and plant collapse.
Balanced Pumpkin Dataset/Downy_Mildew.timeline_metric: URGENT (24-72 Hours) - Immediate application of systemic and contact fungicides is crucial to stop explosive spread.

organic_solution.strategy: Requires rigorous sanitation and proactive application of copper or peroxide-based treatments to sterilize foliage.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide (e.g., Kocide, Champion)
products.details: Protective contact fungicide (FRAC M1) for Oomycetes.

products.name: Peroxide/Peracetic Acid (ZeroTol/OxiDate)
products.details: Peroxide-based cleaner useful in killing overwintering mycelia and oospores.[1]

chemical_solution.strategy: Use fungicide mixtures that combine systemic and protective MoAs, alternating chemical groups (4, 40, 11, M3, M5) for full protection against resistance.

products.name: Metalaxyl-M + Chlorothalonil (e.g., Ridomil Gold)
products.details: Combination of systemic Phenylamide (FRAC 4) and protective Nitrile (FRAC M5).

products.name: Dimethomorph + Mancozeb (Acrobat MZ)
products.details: Systemic Cinnamic acid (FRAC 40) + multi-site Dithiocarbamate (FRAC M3) pre-mix. Highly effective Oomycete specific control.[4]

prevention_tips: Avoid late-day watering that keeps leaves wet overnight.
Use resistant or tolerant Giraumon varieties if available.
Ensure maximum ventilation in protected structures to reduce leaf wetness.

Balanced Pumpkin Dataset/Bacterial_Leaf_.description: Bacterial disease caused by Pseudomonas syringae pv. lachrymans. Symptoms are angular, water-soaked spots confined by leaf veins, often exuding a sticky ooze. Survives on seeds and crop debris for years.
Balanced Pumpkin Dataset/Bacterial_Leaf_.timeline_metric: PROMPT (3-5 Days) - Requires immediate cultural changes and application of suppressive agents to limit bacterial multiplication.

organic_solution.strategy: Strict cultural controls, sanitation, and protective applications are the only means of control, as no systemic cure exists.

products.name: Pruning/Sanitation
products.details: Removal of lower, infected leaves to increase air flow and reduce disease pressure.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide/Oxychloride (e.g., CUPER, Champion)
products.details: Apply copper products (FRAC M1) as frequent suppressive sprays, focusing on new growth.

chemical_solution.strategy: Apply copper bactericides restrictively, only for suppression on developing fruit and foliage, and always rotate with cultural controls.

products.name: Copper + Mancozeb Tank Mix
products.details: Combination of Copper (M1) and protective Mancozaeb (M3) to enhance bacterial suppression.

products.name: Kasugamycin (if permitted locally)
products.details: Antibiotic bactericide used in rotation to manage copper resistance.

prevention_tips: Practice long crop rotation (2+ years) with non-cucurbit crops.
Use certified disease-free seed; hot water treatment can reduce seed-borne bacteria.
Avoid working in the field when plants are wet, as this spreads the bacteria.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Soft_Rot.description: A destructive bacterial disease causing tubers to become soft, mushy, slimy, and develop a foul odor, typically starting from wounds or the stolon end. It thrives in warm, humid, and poorly drained conditions.

organic_solution.strategy: Strictly focus on cultural control: improving drainage, sanitation, and proper storage management (cool, dry).

products.name: Sanitation & Curing
products.details: Remove infected tubers immediately. Cure harvested tubers by holding them at 10°C–15°C with high humidity for 10-14 days to heal wounds before long-term storage.

products.name: Copper Oxychloride (Preventative)
products.details: Can be used as a soil or post-harvest surface treatment to suppress bacterial entry (if permitted locally).

chemical_solution.strategy: There is no curative field spray for soft rot in potato. Focus on seed treatment and post-harvest application to prevent spread in storage.

products.name: Streptomycin Sulphate + Tetracycline HCL (Kmycin)
products.details: Use an approved antibiotic combination for seed or post-harvest treatment to minimize bacterial inoculum.

products.name: Chlorothalonil (e.g., Bravo)
products.details: Effective in controlling late blight/Phytophthora, which often causes wounds that allow soft rot entry. (FRAC M5)

Balanced Potato Dataset/Soft_Rot.pathogen_timeline: Infection occurs rapidly through wounds in warm, wet soil, but symptoms accelerate drastically in storage if temperature and humidity are high.
prevention_tips: Plant certified, disease-free seed tubers.
Avoid planting in poorly drained fields.
Maintain tuber pulp temperature below 15°C during harvest.
Ensure proper ventilation during storage.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Potato_Late_blig.description: The most destructive Oomycete disease, causing dark, water-soaked lesions that rapidly spread on leaves and stems, often with white, fuzzy mold on the underside. Can destroy a crop in days, especially in cool

organic_solution.strategy: Aggressive removal of infected material and high-concentration copper-based treatments applied preventatively at short intervals.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide (e.g., Kocide)
products.details: Apply protectant at very tight intervals (e.g., 4–5 days) during high-risk weather (FRAC M1).

products.name: Sanitation & Haulm Desiccation
products.details: Immediately destroy infected plants. After top growth dies (haulm desiccation), leave the crop for at least 21 days before harvest to prevent tuber infection.

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires immediate, tight-interval (5-day) application using highly effective contact-systemic rotations to achieve curative action and manage resistance (FRAC rotation is critical).

products.name: Metalaxyl-M + Mancozeb (e.g., Ridomil Gold)
products.details: Combination of systemic (FRAC 4) and protective (FRAC M3) for curative knockdown. Apply at flowering and 14 days later.

products.name: Fluazinam (e.g., Shirlan)
products.details: Low-risk contact fungicide (FRAC 29) for alternation to reduce sporulation and tuber infection. Use in alternation with Group 4.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Potato_Late_blig.pathogen_timeline: Infection can occur in ~10 hours under ideal cool and humid conditions. The reproductive potential is very high, capable of 100% crop loss.
prevention_tips: Avoid irrigating shortly after high-risk weather periods.
Ensure thorough haulm destruction before harvest.
Use resistant potato cultivars if available.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Potato_Early_bli.description: A common fungal disease causing large, dark brown spots, typically on older foliage, with characteristic concentric rings (bullseye). Favored by warm weather and wet/dry cycles.

organic_solution.strategy: Sanitation and protective Copper barrier sprays are the primary defense, combined with proper nutrition to maintain plant vigor.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide (e.g., Kocide)
products.details: Apply Copper-based fungicides (FRAC M1) preventatively as symptoms appear or crop stress occurs.

products.name: Balanced Nutrition
products.details: Ensure proper fertilization (especially Nitrogen, Phosphorus, Potassium) to maintain optimum growing conditions and plant immunity.

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires a strong rotation between protectant (M5) and highly effective systemic fungicides (Groups 7 and 11) to manage established infections, applied at 7- to 10-day intervals.

products.name: Chlorothalonil (e.g., Bravo)
products.details: Apply as a contact protectant (FRAC M5).

products.name: Azoxystrobin (e.g., Quadris) or Boscalid (e.g., Endura)
products.details: Alternate with systemic fungicides (FRAC 11 or FRAC 7) for robust control and resistance management.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Potato_Early_bli.pathogen_timeline: Foliar infection cycles repeat rapidly, causing spore dispersal during dry, windy conditions. Control is justified only when the disease starts early enough to cause economic loss.
prevention_tips: Grow later-maturing varieties.
Avoid irrigation methods that lead to prolonged leaf wetness.
Apply fungicides as soon as early symptoms appear.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Phytophthora.description: Tuber infection caused by the same agent as Late Blight. Leads to internal reddish-brown rot and is a major pathway for secondary Soft Rot in storage.

organic_solution.strategy: Focus completely on preventing spores from reaching the tubers (killing the haulm completely).

products.name: Sanitation & Field Management
products.details: Ensure thorough haulm desiccation. Leave crops for at least 21 days after haulm destruction before harvest to ensure all spores in the soil are dead.

chemical_solution.strategy: The same high-efficacy systemic and contact fungicides used for Late Blight foliage control are required to reduce spore load in the field prior to harvest.

products.name: Metalaxyl-M + Mancozeb (e.g., Ridomil Gold)
products.details: Systemic and contact combination (FRAC 4 + M3) for final field protection prior to desiccation.

products.name: Phosphites (e.g., Phostrol)
products.details: Can be applied post-harvest for stored potatoes to inhibit rot spread (FRAC 33).

Balanced Potato Dataset/Phytophthora.pathogen_timeline: Tuber infection happens as the tuber passes through contaminated soil during harvest or via spores washing down from the foliage.
prevention_tips: Harvesting equipment must be thoroughly cleaned between blighted and healthy crops.
Ensure complete haulm desiccation and avoid haulm re-growth before lifting.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Pink_Rot.description: A tuber decay that starts rubbery and odorless, but when a cut infected tuber is exposed to air, the rotted portion turns a salmon pink color (later brown/black). Activated by warm, saturated soil.

organic_solution.strategy: Strict environmental control and proper storage management are the key, as the pathogen thrives only in saturated soil.

products.name: Good Drainage/Irrigation Control
products.details: Avoid prolonged soil saturation (waterlogging). Minimize wounding during harvesting.

products.name: Low-Temperature Storage
products.details: Maintain low temperatures in storage, as the fungus is inactive below this threshold.

chemical_solution.strategy: Fungicide application is recommended 2 and 4 weeks before harvest in fields with a history of pink rot, using systemic oomycete-specific products.

products.name: Mefenoxam/Mancozeb (e.g., Ridomil Gold MZ)
products.details: Pre-harvest application (FRAC 4 + M3) at flowering and again 14 days later.

products.name: Phosphites (e.g., Phostrol)
products.details: Post-harvest application to stored tubers (FRAC 33).

Balanced Potato Dataset/Pink_Rot.pathogen_timeline: Develops in mature plants approaching harvest, especially in warm, saturated soil. Decay continues in storage.
prevention_tips: Avoid harvesting wet tubers or tubers with pulp temperatures above.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Dry_Rot.description: A fungal disease of tubers, often starting at wounds, causing internal decay that is dry, brown, or black with cavities and white/pink fungal growth. Thrives in dry, cool storage conditions after initial field infection.

organic_solution.strategy: Strict sanitation, crop rotation, and the use of bio-fungicides applied at planting or pre-storage.

products.name: Trichoderma fungus-based biopesticides
products.details: Exploitation of specific *Trichoderma* strains to enhance biological control against Fusarium in the soil or storage environment (NC).

products.name: Neem Oil / Garlic Extracts
products.details: Organic substances with antifungal properties for topical or post-harvest application.

chemical_solution.strategy: Fungicide seed treatment or post-harvest application is crucial, focusing on Benzimidazole or Strobilurin groups.

products.name: Benzimidazole-based fungicides
products.details: Seed treatment to inhibit the development of Fusarium dry rot (FRAC 1).

products.name: Azoxystrobin (e.g., Quadris)
products.details: Strobilurin fungicides (FRAC 11) for field control, providing control against various fungal pathogens.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Dry_Rot.pathogen_timeline: Fungal spores enter tubers via wounds during harvest/handling. Decay develops and spreads rapidly during the storage phase.
prevention_tips: Avoid wounding tubers during harvest and handling.
Rotate crops to break the disease cycle.
Ensure good ventilation and low humidity during storage.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Brown_Rot.description: A destructive bacterial wilt, causing wilting of young leaves, stunting, and eventual plant death. On tubers, it causes a brown discoloration of the vascular ring (ring rot) and often a bacterial ooze.

organic_solution.strategy: Extremely strict cultural and sanitation controls, as the pathogen is highly contagious and persistent. Use bio-formulations to boost plant health.

products.name: Quarantine & Sanitation
products.details: This is a quarantine disease (in many regions, including Mauritius). Immediately remove and destroy infected plants. Strict tool and equipment sanitation is vital.

products.name: Plant Growth Promoting Bacteria (PGPB)
products.details: Use bioformulations of beneficial bacteria to boost yield and potentially reduce infestation in the soil.

chemical_solution.strategy: No effective chemical curative treatment exists; control is limited to preventive measures and seed quality management.

products.name: Fungicide and Insecticide Seed Treatment
products.details: All imported seed must be treated with fungicide and insecticide (Required by Mauritian regulation).

Balanced Potato Dataset/Brown_Rot.pathogen_timeline: Symptoms appear at any stage of plant growth, with wilting often starting during the hottest part of the day. The bacterium is highly contagious and persistent.
prevention_tips: Use certified disease-free seed tubers.
Practice long-term crop rotation.
Strictly regulate movement of plant material and equipment.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Common_Scab.description: Reduces market value due to obnoxious scab lesions (corky, raised spots) on the tuber skin. Severe in fields with high inoculum, in sandy/lime soils, and during dry conditions.

organic_solution.strategy: Cultural control focuses on maintaining soil moisture and pH management (acidifying the soil).

products.name: Elemental Sulphur Application
products.details: Adding elemental sulphur can reduce soil pH, which suppresses the growth of the causal organism (*S. scabies*).

products.name: NPK/Magnesium Fertilization
products.details: Balanced NPK and Magnesium fertilization improves tuber quality and enhances resistance to the pathogen.

chemical_solution.strategy: Control is primarily through seed treatment to manage seed-borne inoculum.

products.name: Dithane M45 (Mancozeb)
products.details: Dust tubers at a rate of 3 kg per tonne of seeds to control seed-borne infection, treated before sprouts are 2 mm long (FRAC M03).

Balanced Potato Dataset/Common_Scab.pathogen_timeline: The organism is soil-borne and seed-borne. Infection is favored by dry conditions.
prevention_tips: Avoid applying factory scums in potato furrows, as they favor disease development (MSIRI recommendation).
Avoid planting in fields with high inoculum or high pH.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Blackspot_Bruisi.description: Internal non-disease issue: grey/black discoloration spots on the potato flesh visible when the skin is removed. Caused by physical impact/bruising in dry or warm conditions, leading to cell damage and oxidation (tyrosine to melanin).

organic_solution.strategy: Focus exclusively on cultural practices and balanced nutrition to strengthen tuber structure and minimize physical impact.

products.name: Pre-Harvest Water Management
products.details: Reduce watering for two weeks before harvest to toughen tuber skins.

products.name: Potassium, Magnesium, and Boron
products.details: Ensure high levels of Potassium, Magnesium, and Boron in the soil, as low levels increase susceptibility to enzymatic blackening.

chemical_solution.strategy: No chemical treatment corrects the bruising, but proper fertilization is a key part of the solution.

products.name: Balanced NPK/Nutrient Program
products.details: Implement a fertigation program tailored to ensure sufficient levels of K, Mg, and B to reduce phenol oxidation.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Blackspot_Bruisi.pathogen_timeline: Damage occurs immediately upon impact, but the discoloration (oxidation reaction) is visible 1–3 days after the cell damage.
prevention_tips: Pad chains and equipment used during harvesting and handling.
Harvest potatoes when tuber pulp temperatures are cool.
Select varieties known to be less susceptible to bruising.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Blackleg.description: A common bacterial disease causing stunted growth, yellowing stems, and a characteristic black rot at the stem base at or below ground level. Infected tubers may rot in the field or storage.

organic_solution.strategy: Prompt removal and destruction of infected plants, combined with dry storage conditions and good drainage.

products.name: Sanitation and Destruction
products.details: Promptly remove and destroy infected plants (and tubers) as soon as symptoms are noticed to prevent spread.

products.name: Soil Management
products.details: Improve poorly drained sites and lift crops during dry weather. Practice crop rotation.

chemical_solution.strategy: No effective chemical controls are available for the gardener/farmer once the disease is established; focus is on clean seed and prevention.

products.name: Certified Seed Tubers
products.details: The most important preventive measure is using certified seed with very low (or zero) levels of infection.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Blackleg.pathogen_timeline: One of the earliest potato diseases to appear, typically in wet years. The bacteria survive over winter in infected volunteer tubers and plant debris.
prevention_tips: Use certified seed and avoid saving your own seed if the disease is present.
Ensure dry storage of seed or ware potatoes.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Black_Scurf.disease_name: Black Scurf and Stem Canker (Rhizoctonia solani)
Balanced Potato Dataset/Black_Scurf.description: Fungal disease causing two main problems: 1) Black scurf: hard, raised black spots (sclerotia) on the tuber surface that can be scraped off. 2) Stem canker: brown, sunken patches on stems/stolons leading to stunted, yellowed plants.

organic_solution.strategy: Promote early emergence to help vigorous plants outgrow the infection. Use biological control agents.

products.name: Trichoderma harzianum (Biofungicide)
products.details: Apply biological fungicide in the furrows to reduce the incidence of black scurf.

products.name: Soil Warming/Shallow Planting
products.details: Plant seed tubers in warm soil and in shallower furrows to allow for earlier shoot emergence.

chemical_solution.strategy: Seed and in-furrow treatments at planting are the most effective chemical measures, using specific fungicides.

products.name: Fluodioxinil (Seed Treatment)
products.details: Fungicide seed treatment to prevent spread of the seed-borne pathogen.

products.name: Azoxystrobin (In-Furrow)
products.details: Apply QoI fungicide (FRAC 11) in the furrow at planting to control the progression of the fungus in the soil.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Black_Scurf.pathogen_timeline: Disease promoted by cold planting conditions where plant growth is inhibited. The fungus survives for long periods in the soil.
prevention_tips: Use seed material from certified sources, free of infection.
Practice long rotations to reduce disease levels in the soil.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Nematode.description: Microscopic worm-like pests that cause injured/rotted roots, excessive root branching, and damage to tubers (dark spots, dry and cracked surfaces, reddish-brown lesions).

organic_solution.strategy: Cultural practices to disrupt the life cycle and biological controls to suppress populations.

products.name: Crop Rotation & Cover Crops
products.details: Rotate with non-host crops and use cover crops (like certain grasses or rapeseed) to suppress nematode populations.

products.name: Organic Matter / Solarization
products.details: Add organic matter (manure, compost) to increase beneficial microorganisms. Cover soil with plastic during summer (solarization) to reduce temperatures.

chemical_solution.strategy: Use specialized nematicides (Group 3A) for control, prioritizing those with favorable toxicological profiles.

products.name: Fluensulfone (e.g., Nimitz)
products.details: An innovative nematicide (FRAC 3A) providing best-in-class control of root-knot nematodes with a favorable safety profile compared to older chemistries.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Nematode.pathogen_timeline: Nematodes stop feeding within one hour of contact with effective nematicides, with complete mortality of active stages achieved in 24 to 72 hours.
prevention_tips: Regularly weed fields, as weeds can host nematodes.
Thoroughly destroy the roots immediately after the crop has been picked.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Virus.description: A complex of viral diseases causing mosaic symptoms, leaf rolling, stunting, and reduced yield. Spread primarily by insect vectors (like aphids) or mechanically (tools, hands). No cure exists.

organic_solution.strategy: Strictly focus on using virus-free seed and aggressive vector control.

products.name: Certified Virus-Free Seed
products.details: Planting certified, virus-free seed is the most critical preventative measure.

products.name: Mineral Oil / Insecticidal Soap
products.details: Apply to foliage to disrupt aphid feeding and transmission.

chemical_solution.strategy: Focus entirely on systemic insecticides to control aphid vectors and prevent virus transmission.

products.name: Imidacloprid (e.g., Confidor)
products.details: Systemic neonicotinoid (Group 4A) used for sucking pest control. Apply as seed treatment or foliar spray.

products.name: Flonicamid (e.g., Strangle)
products.details: Specific aphicide (IRAC 29) for excellent knockdown control. Use in rotation.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Virus.pathogen_timeline: No cure. Symptoms appear after inoculation. Focus is on vector control to prevent rapid spread across the field.
prevention_tips: Immediately rogue and destroy any suspicious plants.
Control volunteer potato plants and weeds, which can harbor viruses or vectors.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Miscellaneous.disease_name: Miscellaneous Pests (Tuber Moth, Leaf Miner, etc.)
Balanced Potato Dataset/Miscellaneous.description: General category for insect pests that may impact potato foliage or tubers.

organic_solution.strategy: Apply biological and botanical controls targeting general chewing and sucking pests.

products.name: Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt)
products.details: Specific biological insecticide for control of chewing pests (e.g., bollworm, moth larvae).

products.name: Neem Oil
products.details: Broad-spectrum botanical insecticide/repellent for many pests.

chemical_solution.strategy: Integrated Pest Management (IPM) using targeted chemical rotations as required by scouting.

products.name: Lambda-Cyhalothrin
products.details: Broad-spectrum synthetic pyrethroid (Group 3A) for fast knockdown of many pests.

products.name: Emamectin Benzoate
products.details: Non-systemic insecticide (Group 6) for caterpillar/moth control, used in rotation.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Miscellaneous.pathogen_timeline: Control measures should be implemented immediately upon reaching economic thresholds identified by field scouting.
prevention_tips: Regularly scout the field (weekly inspection) to detect early pest signs.
Ensure healthy crops through balanced nutrition and proper water management.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Healthy_Potatoes.description: The plant exhibits strong vigor, dense canopy, deep green color, and high yield potential, demonstrating successful preventative measures and adequate nutrition.

organic_solution.strategy: Focus on continuous preventative nutritional and cultural management to maintain optimal health and resilience.

products.name: Microbial Inoculants (Trichoderma)
products.details: Apply as preventative soil drenches to suppress endemic soil-borne pathogens before they establish.

products.name: Compost Tea / Bio-stimulant
products.details: Use to promote beneficial microbial activity and enhance plant vitality.

chemical_solution.strategy: Implement a balanced fertigation program tailored to the potato growth stage (tuber initiation, bulking, maturation).

products.name: Balanced NPK Fertilizer
products.details: Use a complete NPK fertilizer program to meet crop stage needs.

products.name: Calcium/Boron Foliar Spray
products.details: Apply to support cell wall strength and reduce risk of bruising/storage issues.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Healthy_Potatoes.pathogen_timeline: N/A. Focus is on continuous preventative management to maintain optimal health and resilience.
prevention_tips: Implement a strong Integrated Pest Management (IPM) plan.
Rotate crops to break disease cycles.
Plant certified, high-quality seed material.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Fungi.description: General fungal diseases causing stem, root, or tuber rots, often leading to massive economic losses (e.g., Stem Rot by *Neocosmospora rubicola* causing grayish-black streaking and stunting).

organic_solution.strategy: Focus on high-quality seed, crop rotation, and increasing the soil's beneficial microbial population.

products.name: Bio-Formulations (PGPB)
products.details: Apply Plant Growth Promoting Bacteria (PGPB) bioformulations to enhance plant uptake efficiency and suppress pathogen infestation.

products.name: Crop Rotation
products.details: Break the disease cycle by rotating with non-host crops to reduce the survival of the pathogen.

chemical_solution.strategy: Use a preventative fungicide seed treatment that is effective against soil-borne fungi (e.g., Fusarium, Rhizoctonia).

products.name: Seed Treatment (e.g., Thiophanate-methyl + Mancozeb)
products.details: Use an effective seed treatment combination to control the initial seed-borne fungal inoculum (FRAC 1 + M3).

Balanced Potato Dataset/Fungi.pathogen_timeline: Most fungal pathogens are seed-borne or survive as resting structures in the soil and are favored by environmental conditions and infected seeds.
prevention_tips: Select resistant potato cultivars where available.
Ensure proper fertilization to reduce plant stress.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Black_Dot.description: Fungal disease causing numerous black microsclerotia (small dots) on the stem, stolons, and tuber skin surface. Can lead to early foliage death (early blight-like symptoms). Recently reported in Mauritius.

organic_solution.strategy: Sanitation and preventative cultural control, focusing on reducing the soil inoculum.

products.name: Seed Surface Disinfection
products.details: Surface disinfect seed tubers with a 10% bleach (sodium hypochlorite) solution before planting.

products.name: Crop Debris Management
products.details: Remove and destroy crop debris, as the fungus survives through sclerotia on old host residues.

chemical_solution.strategy: Use fungicides with demonstrated efficacy against *Colletotrichum* species, often QoI and SDHI groups.

products.name: Azoxystrobin (e.g., Ortiva/Quadris)
products.details: QoI fungicide (FRAC 11) is effective against *Colletotrichum* species for foliar/in-furrow application.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Black_Dot.pathogen_timeline: Sclerotia (black dots) can survive for long periods. Symptoms were observed on stems and tubers in Mauritius in August-September.
prevention_tips: Use long crop rotations (non-potato crops).
Monitor closely for stem symptoms just above the soil level.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Bacteria.description: General category for bacterial infections beyond Soft Rot (e.g., Blackleg, Brown Rot) which are often water-borne, highly persistent, and enter through wounds or seed.

organic_solution.strategy: Strict sanitation, high-quality seed, and moisture management are the only reliable defenses.

products.name: Water and Soil Management
products.details: Avoid water-logged conditions and do not work in the field when plants are wet to prevent bacterial spread.

products.name: Copper Compounds
products.details: Apply Copper-based products as a general surface bactericide (FRAC M1).

chemical_solution.strategy: Focus on the initial seed inoculum using approved antibiotic treatments for prevention.

products.name: Antibiotic Treatments (e.g., Streptomycin)
products.details: Apply approved antibiotic combinations as a seed treatment.

Balanced Potato Dataset/Bacteria.pathogen_timeline: Highly contagious and persistent. Symptoms can develop rapidly in favorable conditions.
prevention_tips: Sanitize all tools and machinery between fields.
Use certified, disease-free seed tubers.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Ringspot.description: A devastating viral disease causing severe yellowing, mosaic patterns, 'shoestring' leaf deformation, and characteristic dark green rings on the fruit. Spread rapidly by aphid vectors. No cure exists.

organic_solution.strategy: Strict sanitation, aggressive roguing (removal of infected plants), and vector control are the only methods.

products.name: Horticultural Oil / Neem Oil
products.details: Apply regularly to reduce aphid populations and disrupt virus transmission.

products.name: Cross-Protection (PRSV-P strain)
products.details: Using a mild strain of PRSV to inoculate young plants for protection against severe strains (requires governmental approval).

chemical_solution.strategy: Focus entirely on systemic insecticides to suppress aphid populations and prevent transmission.

products.name: Imidacloprid (e.g., Confidor)
products.details: Systemic neonicotinoid (Group 4A) used for sucking pest control.

products.name: Flonicamid (e.g., Strangle)
products.details: Specific aphicide (IRAC 29) for excellent knockdown control. Use in rotation.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Ringspot.pathogen_timeline: No cure. Spread is rapid (can be minutes) after aphid feeding. Diseased trees must be destroyed immediately.
prevention_tips: Plant certified, disease-free seedlings.
Immediately rogue and destroy (bury or burn) any plant showing symptoms.
Keep fields free of weeds, which harbor aphids.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Powdery_Mildew.description: Fungal disease appearing as white, powdery patches on the leaf surface, usually on the underside. Causes leaves to yellow and drop prematurely. Favored by high humidity and poor air circulation.

organic_solution.strategy: Easily managed with environmental controls and sulfur-based or bio-control sprays.

products.name: Wettable Sulphur
products.details: Apply elemental sulfur spray (FRAC M02) as a contact fungicide. Caution: Do not use above 30°C.

products.name: Potassium Bicarbonate
products.details: Use a solution as a contact fungicide/wash.

chemical_solution.strategy: Utilize sulfur and targeted systemic fungicides (Group 3 DMI).

products.name: Difenoconazole (e.g., Score 250 EC)
products.details: Apply a DMI fungicide (FRAC 3) for systemic and curative action.

products.name: Myclobutanil (e.g., Systhane)
products.details: Alternate with another DMI fungicide (FRAC 3) to prevent resistance, often used preventatively.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Powdery_Mildew.pathogen_timeline: Spreads rapidly under favorable conditions. Weekly application is required to manage existing growth and protect new foliage.
prevention_tips: Ensure good air circulation within the orchard.
Prune lower leaves to allow air penetration.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Mosaic.description: Viral disease causing distinct yellow mosaic patterns, blisters, and mottled appearance on leaves and fruit. Less severe than PRSV, but still causes significant yield loss. Spread by aphids and potentially mechanical means.

organic_solution.strategy: Same strategy as PRSV: immediate roguing and vector control.

products.name: Mineral Oil
products.details: Used as a foliar spray to disrupt aphid transmission.

products.name: Sanitation (Tool Cleaning)
products.details: Clean pruning tools with a 10% bleach solution after handling any suspicious tree to prevent mechanical spread.

chemical_solution.strategy: Vector control is key. Use systemic insecticides in rotation to control aphid populations.

products.name: Acetamiprid
products.details: Neonicotinoid (Group 4A) used in alternation with Imidacloprid to reduce resistance pressure.

products.name: Pyriproxyfen (e.g., Admiral)
products.details: Insect Growth Regulator (IRAC 7C) used to disrupt the whitefly/aphid lifecycle.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Mosaic.pathogen_timeline: Spread by aphids and sometimes through mechanical means. Immediate removal of symptomatic plants is critical for containment.
prevention_tips: Ensure all incoming seedlings are certified virus-free.
Plant non-host buffer crops around the orchard perimeter.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Mite_disease.disease_name: Papaya Mites (e.g., Texas Citrus Mite/Broad Mite)
Balanced Papaya Dataset/Mite_disease.description: Tiny arachnid pests that cause bronzing or russeting of leaves, stunting, and deformation of young leaves and flower buds. Broad Mites cause the most damage to the growing points.

organic_solution.strategy: Utilize biological control (predators) and specific botanical or biological miticides, ensuring excellent coverage of the leaf underside.

products.name: Predatory Mites (Amblyseius spp.)
products.details: Biological control agent. Release predatory mites for continuous control.

products.name: Horticultural Oil / Insecticidal Soap
products.details: Apply for contact kill, ensuring high-volume spray for good coverage.

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires specialized miticides (acaricides). Resistance management is critical; rotate strictly between IRAC Groups.

products.name: Abamectin (e.g., Abamec 1.8 EC)
products.details: Highly effective miticide (IRAC Group 6). Apply with high pressure to reach hidden mites.

products.name: Spirodiclofen (e.g., Envidor)
products.details: Specific miticide (IRAC 23) that targets all life stages, used for rotation.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Mite_disease.pathogen_timeline: Extremely rapid lifecycle, leading to fast population increase in hot, dry weather. Effective control stops new damage within 3-4 days.
prevention_tips: Avoid planting near citrus or ornamental plants known to harbor mites.
Regularly monitor new growth (the most susceptible part) for early signs.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Mealybug.description: Soft, oval, white, cottony insects that feed on sap, especially on tender growth and fruit. Cause stunting and secrete sticky 'honeydew', which leads to black sooty mold development.

organic_solution.strategy: Utilize natural enemies and contact sprays (soap/oil) to wash away the insects and the protective wax coating.

products.name: Biological Control (Ladybeetles/Parasitoids)
products.details: Conserve or release natural predators like Cryptolaemus montrouzieri (Mealybug Destroyer).

products.name: Insecticidal Soap / Horticultural Oil
products.details: Apply for contact kill, ensuring thorough saturation to penetrate the waxy coating.

chemical_solution.strategy: Systemic insecticides are the most effective way to reach clustered and hidden mealybugs. Use only targeted products to preserve beneficial insects.

products.name: Buprofezin (e.g., Applaud)
products.details: Insect Growth Regulator (IRAC 16) targeting immatures; low impact on beneficials.

products.name: Movento (Spirotetramat)
products.details: Two-way systemic insecticide (IRAC 23) that moves up and down the plant, reaching concealed pests.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Mealybug.pathogen_timeline: Populations can grow slowly but severely damage flowers and fruit leading to quality loss. Control required immediately upon detection.
prevention_tips: Avoid excess nitrogen fertilization, which promotes the tender growth favored by mealybugs.
Ant control is crucial, as ants protect mealybugs from natural enemies.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Curl.description: A virus transmitted by the **Whitefly** (*Bemisia tabaci*). Causes severe upward curling and crinkling of young leaves, thickening of veins, and stunting. **No cure.**

organic_solution.strategy: Strict sanitation and aggressive whitefly vector control.

products.name: Yellow Sticky Traps
products.details: Use traps to monitor and reduce whitefly populations in the field.

products.name: Neem Oil / Insecticidal Soap
products.details: Apply contact sprays frequently (every 5-7 days) to suppress whitefly numbers.

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires the rotation of systemic insecticides and Insect Growth Regulators (IGRs) to manage resistance in the whitefly vector.

products.name: Imidacloprid (e.g., Confidor)
products.details: Apply a neonicotinoid (Group 4A) as a drench or foliar spray for control of whiteflies.

products.name: Spiromesifen (e.g., OZIL)
products.details: Alternate with a Group 23 insecticide targeting eggs and immature stages (I GR).

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Curl.pathogen_timeline: No cure. Symptoms develop after whitefly transmission. Immediate removal and destruction of infected plants is the only way to stop local spread.
prevention_tips: Plant in areas isolated from cotton or tobacco, which also host whiteflies.
Use resistant or tolerant cultivars if available.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Black_Spot.description: Fungal disease causing numerous small, dark spots on the underside of older leaves, often with a grayish-white center. Leads to premature leaf drop and sunscald on fruit.

organic_solution.strategy: Sanitation and preventative Copper barrier sprays are the primary defense, combined with canopy management.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide (e.g., Kocide)
products.details: Apply Copper-based fungicides (FRAC M1) preventatively before rainy periods.

products.name: Pruning/Air Circulation
products.details: Remove heavily infected lower leaves and old, senescing leaves to reduce humidity and inoculum.

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires rotation between broad-spectrum contact protectants (Group M) and systemic fungicides (Group 11).

products.name: Chlorothalonil (e.g., Bravo 720 SC)
products.details: Apply as a broad-spectrum contact protectant (FRAC M05).

products.name: Azoxystrobin (e.g., Ortiva 250 SC)
products.details: Alternate with a systemic QoI fungicide (FRAC 11) for curative and protective action.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Black_Spot.pathogen_timeline: Disease favors leaf wetness (rain/dew) for spore germination. Regular preventative application is necessary, especially during the humid season.
prevention_tips: Avoid overhead irrigation.
Ensure proper plant spacing for maximum air flow.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/BacterialSpot.description: Bacterial infection causing small, angular, water-soaked, dark spots on leaves, often concentrated at leaf margins. Can lead to large necrotic areas and leaf drop. Favored by warm, wet conditions.

organic_solution.strategy: Strict sanitation and proactive use of Copper compounds, which act as surface bactericides.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide/Oxychloride
products.details: Apply Copper products (FRAC M1) every 7-10 days, focusing on new growth.

products.name: Sanitation/Field Hygiene
products.details: Avoid working in the orchard when plants are wet. Immediately remove heavily infected leaves.

chemical_solution.strategy: The standard treatment is Copper bactericide application, sometimes tank-mixed with Mancozeb to enhance efficacy.

products.name: Copper + Mancozeb Tank Mix
products.details: Apply a tank mix of Copper Hydroxide (M1) and Mancozeb (M03) for enhanced bacterial suppression and fungal control.

products.name: Kasugamycin
products.details: In rotation, apply an approved antibiotic (FRAC 24) to manage resistance risk (if permitted locally).

Balanced Papaya Dataset/BacterialSpot.pathogen_timeline: Spreads rapidly during rain and periods of high humidity. No systemic cure exists; copper compounds suppress multiplication on the surface.
prevention_tips: Use certified disease-free seedlings.
Avoid overhead irrigation which promotes leaf wetness.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Anthracnose.description: A fungal disease causing dark, sunken lesions on the fruit, especially during ripening. On leaves, it causes water-soaked spots that dry up and turn dark. It is a major post-harvest disease.

organic_solution.strategy: Cultural control to minimize fruit wounding and preventative application of Copper/Neem-based products.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide
products.details: Apply copper-based protectant sprays (FRAC M1) regularly during the fruit development stage.

products.name: Hot Water Treatment (Post-Harvest)
products.details: Treat fruit in hot water for 20 minutes immediately after harvest to kill latent spores before storage/transport.

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires preventative foliar application of broad-spectrum fungicides (FRAC M) during the fruiting phase, combined with post-harvest treatment.

products.name: Chlorothalonil (e.g., Bravo 720 SC)
products.details: Apply as a contact protectant (FRAC M05) during fruit set and bulking.

products.name: Prochloraz (Post-Harvest Dip)
products.details: Use an approved post-harvest fungicide dip to prevent latent infections from developing in storage/transit (FRAC 3).

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Anthracnose.pathogen_timeline: Infection occurs when fruit is young, but symptoms typically remain latent (hidden) until the fruit begins to ripen.
prevention_tips: Harvest fruit only when fully dry to avoid spore spread.
Ensure gentle handling to prevent fruit wounds/bruises.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Healthy.description: The plant exhibits strong vigor, dense canopy, deep green color, and high yield potential, demonstrating successful preventative measures and adequate nutrition.

organic_solution.strategy: Maintain soil fertility and structure. Focus on preventative bio-control applications to suppress endemic pathogens before they establish.

products.name: Microbial Inoculants (Trichoderma)
products.details: Apply as preventative soil drenches.

products.name: Compost Tea / Bio-stimulant
products.details: Use to promote beneficial microbial activity and enhance plant vitality.

chemical_solution.strategy: Implement a balanced fertigation program tailored to the papaya growth stage (vegetative, flowering, fruiting).

products.name: Balanced NPK Fertilizer
products.details: Use a complete NPK fertilizer program to meet crop stage needs, focusing on high K during fruiting.

products.name: Calcium/Boron Foliar Spray
products.details: Apply during flowering/fruiting stage to support fruit set and quality.

Balanced Papaya Dataset/Healthy.pathogen_timeline: N/A. Focus is on continuous preventative management to maintain optimal health and resilience.
prevention_tips: Practice good inter-row weed management.
Maintain a strong integrated pest management (IPM) plan.

Balanced Onion Dataset/Stemphylium_Colle.disease_name: Stemphylium Leaf Blight (Stemphylium vesicarium) and Anthracnose/Colletotrichum Leaf Blight (C. gloeosporioides)
Balanced Onion Dataset/Stemphylium_Colle.description: These are common fungal leaf blights. **Stemphylium** causes small, tan to brown, water-soaked spots that enlarge, often leading to leaf death. **Colletotrichum** (Anthracnose) causes elongated, bleached, or watersoaked lesions that may girdle the leaves. Both are favored by high humidity and rain, causing significant yield loss.

organic_solution.strategy: Crop rotation, sanitation, and preventative Copper or biological treatments are necessary, especially during the humid season.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide (Preventative)
products.details: Apply copper-based fungicides (FRAC M1) as a protective barrier during periods of prolonged leaf wetness (rain/dew).

products.name: Crop Rotation and Sanitation
products.details: Practice long rotation (3+ years) with non-host crops and destroy crop debris completely after harvest.

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires rotation between multi-site protectants and systemic fungicides (Group 3, 7, 11) to manage both diseases and prevent resistance.

products.name: Mancozeb (e.g., Dithane M45)
products.details: Apply as a contact protectant (FRAC M03). Always use in alternation with a systemic product.

products.name: Azoxystrobin/Difenoconazole Mix (e.g., ZODIO)
products.details: Alternate with a systemic QoI + DMI mix (FRAC 11 + 3) for curative control.

Balanced Onion Dataset/Stemphylium_Colle.pathogen_timeline: Fungal spores are spread by wind and water. Disease cycles can be rapid (7-10 days). Control applications must be frequent (7-day intervals) during high-risk periods.
prevention_tips: Use certified disease-free seed or sets.
Ensure good field drainage to avoid prolonged periods of leaf wetness.

Balanced Onion Dataset/Iris_yellow_virus.description: A viral disease causing distinct, elongated, straw-colored or tan spots on leaves and flower stalks, often surrounded by a green halo. Severe infection leads to premature dieback and yield loss. Spread only by the **Onion Thrips** (*Thrips tabaci*). **No cure.**

organic_solution.strategy: Strict sanitation and aggressive thrips vector control are the only recourse.

products.name: Neem Oil / Insecticidal Soap
products.details: Apply frequently (every 5-7 days) with excellent coverage to suppress thrips populations.

products.name: Reflective Mulch
products.details: Use silver or aluminum reflective mulch to deter thrips from landing on plants in the early season.

chemical_solution.strategy: Focus entirely on rotating systemic insecticides to control the thrips vector and prevent further virus spread.

products.name: Spinosad (e.g., Tracer)
products.details: Biological-derived insecticide (Group 5) effective against thrips. Use in alternation with other groups.

products.name: Lambda-Cyhalothrin
products.details: Synthetic pyrethroid (Group 3A) for fast knockdown control of thrips populations when resistance pressure is low.

Balanced Onion Dataset/Iris_yellow_virus.pathogen_timeline: No cure. Spread is directly related to thrips activity. Thrips populations and thus virus incidence peak during dry, warm conditions.
prevention_tips: Destroy all volunteer onions and old crop debris, which harbor both the virus and thrips.
Planting onions away from garlic, chives, or older onion fields.

Balanced Onion Dataset/purple_blotch.description: Fungal disease causing small, water-soaked lesions that rapidly develop into large, purplish-brown spots, often surrounded by a yellow halo. Can cause severe dieback and total yield loss. Favored by high humidity, moderate temperatures, and persistent dew.

organic_solution.strategy: Sanitation, crop rotation, and preventative copper-based treatments are essential.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide (Preventative)
products.details: Apply copper-based fungicides (FRAC M1) as a protective barrier when conditions are favorable for disease.

products.name: Pruning and Debris Removal
products.details: Remove and destroy infected leaves/stems to reduce fungal inoculum in the field.

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires a strong rotation between protectants (M) and highly effective systemic fungicides (Groups 3 and 11) to achieve curative and protective action.

products.name: Chlorothalonil (e.g., Bravo 720 SC)
products.details: Apply as a broad-spectrum contact protectant (FRAC M05).

products.name: Azoxystrobin + Difenoconazole (e.g., ZODIO)
products.details: Alternate with a combined systemic product (FRAC 11 + 3) for robust curative action. Never use these groups exclusively.

Balanced Onion Dataset/purple_blotch.pathogen_timeline: Fungus survives in soil debris. Infection is favored by 18 hours of leaf wetness and temperatures between 20°C and 25°C. Control measures must be preventive and consistent.
prevention_tips: Avoid overhead irrigation, especially in the evening.
Plant in high-density areas that allow for good airflow.

Balanced Onion Dataset/healthy.description: The plant exhibits strong vigor, erect leaves, thick necks, and high yield potential, demonstrating successful preventative measures and adequate nutrition.

organic_solution.strategy: Focus on continuous preventative nutritional and cultural management to maintain optimal health and pest resilience.

products.name: Compost Tea / Bio-stimulant
products.details: Foliar or soil application to promote beneficial microbial activity and enhance plant vitality.

products.name: Seaweed Extract
products.details: Source of micronutrients and phytohormones to reduce plant stress and improve bulb quality.

chemical_solution.strategy: Implement a balanced fertigation program tailored to the onion growth stage (vegetative growth, bulb initiation, bulking).

products.name: High Potassium NPK Fertilizer
products.details: Use a formula with adequate Sulfur and high Potassium during the bulbing phase for quality and storage life.

products.name: Thrips Control (Preventative)
products.details: Apply early-season preventative thrips sprays to minimize the risk of virus transmission.

Balanced Onion Dataset/healthy.pathogen_timeline: N/A. Focus is on continuous preventative management and maintaining dense, healthy foliage.
prevention_tips: Practice crop rotation (at least 3 years) to manage soil-borne inoculum.
Ensure adequate Sulfur nutrition, as it is critical for onion health.
Monitor fields regularly for thrips, especially in dry weather.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Stem_end_Rot.disease_name: Stem End Rot (SER) (Lasiodiplodia theobromae, Botryodiplodia spp.)
Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Stem_end_Rot.description: A major post-harvest fungal disease. Symptoms start as a dark brown to black rot at the **stem end** of the fruit, progressing down. The fungus is present in the tree's vascular system and activates after harvest, especially during warm ripening.

organic_solution.strategy: Cultural control and sanitation are vital. Reduce field inoculum and manage post-harvest heat.

products.name: Sanitation & Pruning
products.details: Remove and destroy dead material (dead twigs, bark, litter) from the canopy and orchard floor to eliminate inoculum source.

products.name: Hot Water Treatment (Post-Harvest)
products.details: Dip harvested fruits in hot water for 20 minutes immediately after harvest to reduce latent fungal spores.

chemical_solution.strategy: Pre-harvest systemic fungicide spray followed by post-harvest chemical or dual treatment is necessary.

products.name: Carbendazim (0.05%) + Propiconazole (0.05%)
products.details: Effective pre-harvest spray combination (15 days before harvest) to reduce SER severity.

products.name: Prochloraz (Post-Harvest Dip)
products.details: Required post-harvest dip to manage SER during controlled atmosphere storage (often used after a hot water/Carbendazim dip).

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Stem_end_Rot.pathogen_timeline: Fungus is often present inside the stem before harvest (endophytic) and spreads during the ripening process (post-harvest).
prevention_tips: Avoid picking immature fruit.
Maintain tree health and water supply during fruit development.
Avoid pruning during wet weather.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Sooty_Mould.disease_name: Sooty Mould (Various Fungi - e.g., Cladosporium, Alternaria)
Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Sooty_Mould.description: Black or dark brown fungal growth on leaves, stems, and fruit surfaces. This mould does **not** attack the plant tissue; it grows on the sticky, sugary 'honeydew' excreted by sap-sucking insects (scale, aphids, mealybugs, whiteflies).

organic_solution.strategy: Address the underlying insect infestation. Once the honeydew source stops, the mould dries up.

products.name: Insecticidal Soap / Neem Oil
products.details: Apply to control the sap-sucking insects (aphids, mealybugs, scale) that produce honeydew.

products.name: Water Wash
products.details: Wiping or sponging affected leaves with water can physically remove the black growth once the insect problem is under control.

chemical_solution.strategy: The mould itself doesn't need chemical treatment; use targeted insecticides to eliminate the honeydew source (sucking pests).

products.name: Imidacloprid (e.g., Confidor)
products.details: Systemic insecticide (Group 4A) effective against aphids, scale, and whiteflies.

products.name: Chlorpyrifos (e.g., CHLORO20)
products.details: Contact insecticide (Group 1B) for scale and mealybug control (use per local regulation).

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Sooty_Mould.pathogen_timeline: The mould appears during periods of insect activity. Once the insects are controlled, the mould will eventually dry and flake off.
prevention_tips: Monitor trees regularly for sap-sucking pests, particularly on new growth.
Control ants, as they protect the honeydew-producing pests.
Ensure proper air circulation through pruning to discourage pest infestation.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Powdery_Mildew.description: One of the most serious mango diseases. Characterized by white, superficial powdery fungal growth on leaves, flower panicles, and young fruits. Causes premature dropping of flowers and fruit, severely reducing crop load.

organic_solution.strategy: Prevention through cultural control and the use of elemental sulfur or bio-fungicides.

products.name: Wettable Sulphur
products.details: Effective organic control. Apply at the panicle emergence stage, alternating with other solutions.

products.name: Bio-fungicides (Bacillus licheniformis)
products.details: Sprays containing *Bacillus* species can reduce powdery mildew infections.

chemical_solution.strategy: Fungicide treatment must start early (before or at very early flowering) with continuous rotation at 7–14 day intervals.

products.name: Carbendazim (e.g., Bavistin)
products.details: Systemic fungicide (Group 1). Apply 3 sprays at 12–15 day intervals during flowering season.

products.name: Myclobutanil (e.g., Systhane)
products.details: DMI fungicide (Group 3). Use in alternation with Carbendazim or Wettable Sulphur to prevent resistance.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Powdery_Mildew.pathogen_timeline: Favored by warm diurnal temperatures and low nocturnal temperatures, combined with high humidity (60–90% RH).
prevention_tips: Prune plants and remove tall weeds to reduce fungal incidence.
Ensure balanced nutrition and avoid high nitrogen fertilization.
Grow mango trees in well-ventilated areas.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Gall_Midge.description: Tiny insect larvae that feed inside mango tissue, causing galls (swollen growths) on leaves, flower buds, and young fruits. This leads to deformed leaves, blossom blight, and fruit drop.

organic_solution.strategy: Cultural control focuses on disrupting the pest life cycle and applying botanical extracts.

products.name: Neem Oil / NSKE (Neem Seed Kernel Extract)
products.details: Apply Neem-based sprays weekly during the new flush and flowering stage to deter adult egg-laying.

products.name: Soil Ploughing
products.details: Plough the soil under the tree canopy to expose and kill pupae stages in the soil.

chemical_solution.strategy: Target the adult egg-laying stage on new flushes (shoots) using systemic or contact insecticides.

products.name: Thiamethoxam 25% WG
products.details: Systemic neonicotinoid (Group 4A) used for sucking and certain chewing pests (e.g., Gall Midge)

products.name: Spinosad (e.g., Tracer)
products.details: Biological-derived insecticide (Group 5) effective against midges and other larvae.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Gall_Midge.pathogen_timeline: Attacks are highest during new shoot emergence and flowering. The larvae drop to the ground to pupate and then emerge as adults to restart the cycle.
prevention_tips: Monitor closely for the start of new flushes to time the sprays accurately.
Use combination insecticides (e.g., Emamectin Benzoate + Thiamethoxam) during peak periods.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Die_Back.description: A serious fungal disease causing twigs and branches to dry and wither, often starting from the tip and moving downward. Symptoms include discoloration of bark, leaves curling upwards, gum exudation, and eventual branch death.

organic_solution.strategy: Surgical removal of infected tissue and application of copper as a preventative sealant.

products.name: Surgical Pruning
products.details: Remove and destroy affected branches, cutting 2–3 inches below the visible infection line into healthy wood.

products.name: Bordeaux Mixture / Copper Oxychloride
products.details: Apply Copper fungicide (0.3%) to the large pruning wounds immediately after cutting and to the whole tree twice a year.

chemical_solution.strategy: Post-pruning wound treatment and systemic fungicide spray for tree-wide protection.

products.name: Thiophanate-methyl (e.g., Bavistin)
products.details: Systemic fungicide (Group 1) proven effective against *B. rhodina*. Use as a spray or paint on pruned ends.

products.name: Azoxystrobin + Difenoconazole (e.g., Azozole)
products.details: Systemic fungicide mix (FRAC 11 + 3) used for general disease control and to prevent further dieback.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Die_Back.pathogen_timeline: Fungus invades the tree's vascular system through wounds (insect damage, mechanical injury). Water and nutrient stress favors the outbreak.
prevention_tips: Avoid damage and lesions to trees, which are the main entry sites.
Ensure balanced nutrition (Zn, Mn, Fe deficiency may favor disease).
Water trees regularly and avoid freezing stress.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Cutting_Weevil.description: The female weevil lays eggs on young leaves and then **cuts the leaf off** at the base, causing the fallen pieces to be found on the ground. This leads to stripped shoots and reduced yield, particularly during the rainy season.

organic_solution.strategy: Manual removal and cultural practices to kill pupae in the soil.

products.name: Collection and Destruction
products.details: Regularly collect and destroy all fallen, egg-loaded pieces of leaves from the orchard floor to break the life cycle.

products.name: Soil Ploughing
products.details: Plough the soil under the tree crowns to kill the pupae stage in the moist soil.

chemical_solution.strategy: Apply insecticides when young leaves are emerging (about 3cm wide) to protect the shoots. Continuous monitoring is needed due to rain wash.

products.name: Deltamethrin / Fenvalerate
products.details: Contact insecticides (Group 3A) for protecting young shoots from weevil attacks (use per local regulations).

products.name: Lambda-Cyhalothrin (e.g., Attack-CS)
products.details: Fast-acting pyrethroid (Group 3A) for knockdown when infestation is severe.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Cutting_Weevil.pathogen_timeline: Pest activity is most visible during the rainy season, synchronizing with the development of new mango shoots.
prevention_tips: Monitor for infestation, especially at the beginning of the rainy season and during young shoot development.
Bagging young shoots with nylon netting has been recommended but is costly.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Black Mould Rot.disease_name: Black Mould Rot (Alternaria alternata - Tuber Rot)
Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Black Mould Rot.description: Also known as **Alternaria Rot** or Black Spot. Causes post-harvest fruit rot, typically starting near the stem end as round, black spots (similar to Lenticels) that expand, often under high humidity.

organic_solution.strategy: Aggressive pre-harvest sanitation and post-harvest heat treatment.

products.name: Pruning and Debris Removal
products.details: Remove infected leaves, twigs, and inflorescences, which serve as the primary source of inoculum.

products.name: Hot Water Treatment (Post-Harvest)
products.details: Brush and hot water treatment is highly effective post-harvest to reduce infection.

chemical_solution.strategy: Regular fungicide applications in the field to reduce inoculum, combined with post-harvest treatment.

products.name: Maneb or Mancozeb
products.details: Apply broad-spectrum protectant fungicide (FRAC M03) starting 2 weeks after fruit set.

products.name: Prochloraz (Post-Harvest Dip)
