products.details: Effective post-harvest dip to prevent rot in storage, often as effective as multiple pre-harvest sprays.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Black Mould Rot.pathogen_timeline: Fruit infection is often latent (hidden) until the fruit begins to ripen, similar to Anthracnose.
prevention_tips: Choose less susceptible varieties like 'Keitt'.
Thin trees to improve ventilation and sun penetration.
Avoid wounding fruit during harvest.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Bacterial_Canker.description: Causes angular, water-soaked spots on leaves (often limited by veins), fruit spots with exudation, and dark lesions/cankers on twigs. Severely reduces fruit quality and is spread by wind and rain splash.

organic_solution.strategy: Prevention is crucial: sanitation, pruning in dry weather, and copper application.

products.name: Copper Fungicides (0.3%)
products.details: Monthly sprays of Copper Oxychloride or Hydroxide are recommended for controlling foliar bacterial infection.

products.name: Dry Pruning & Tool Sanitation
products.details: Prune only during dry periods (spring or summer after harvest) and disinfect all pruning tools between trees.

chemical_solution.strategy: Antibiotics and copper products are used for disease suppression after the first symptoms appear.

products.name: Streptocyclin / Agrimycin
products.details: Apply antibiotic sprays 3 times at 10-day intervals after the first symptoms appear (although effectiveness can be limited).

products.name: Copper Oxychloride (0.3%)
products.details: Apply monthly sprays or immediately to pruning wounds to limit bacterial entry.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Bacterial_Canker.pathogen_timeline: Bacteria enter through wounds (mechanical injuries, insect damage) and natural openings. Spread is highly favored by rain splash.
prevention_tips: Use certified healthy plants and choose resistant varieties.
Use drip irrigation instead of sprinklers to limit moisture on foliage.
Remove and destroy infected parts immediately.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Anthracnose.description: The most destructive field and post-harvest fungal disease worldwide. Causes black spots on leaves, blossom blight (killing flowers), tip dieback, and dark, sunken lesions on mature fruit.

organic_solution.strategy: Cultural control and aggressive copper spraying, especially before and during flowering.

products.name: Copper Fungicides (0.3%)
products.details: Recommended for control of foliar infection, applied after heavy showers.

products.name: Hot Water Treatment (Post-Harvest)
products.details: Dip fruits in hot water for 15 minutes to control post-harvest infection.

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires scheduled pre-harvest sprays to control latent infections and chemical/hot water post-harvest dip.

products.name: Carbendazim (0.1%) (e.g., Bavistin)
products.details: Systemic fungicide (Group 1). Two sprays at 15-day intervals during flowering effectively controls blossom infection.

products.name: Azoxystrobin + Difenoconazole (e.g., ABSOLUTE® 325SC)
products.details: Highly effective systemic mixture (FRAC 11 + 3) for curative and protective control of foliage and latent fruit infection.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Anthracnose.pathogen_timeline: Disease favors high humidity and temperatures. Infection is often latent until fruit ripening begins.
prevention_tips: Prune diseased twigs and burn them with fallen leaves.
Keep out of the orchard when plants are wet to avoid spreading spores.
Ensure proper ventilation and wider plant spacing.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Alternaria.description: Fungal disease causing distinct dark brown to black spots on leaves with concentric rings ('target' pattern). Lesions can coalesce, causing premature leaf drop and reducing photosynthetic capacity.

organic_solution.strategy: Sanitation and preventative barrier sprays, emphasizing improved air flow.

products.name: Copper-Based Formulations
products.details: Broad-spectrum protectants (FRAC M1) for early season foliar application.

products.name: Bio-control (Trichoderma harzianum)
products.details: Mycoparasite that colonizes plant surfaces and inhibits *Alternaria* spore germination.

chemical_solution.strategy: Intelligent rotation between protectants and systemic fungicides (Group 3 and 11) is crucial for resistance management.

products.name: Chlorothalonil (e.g., Bravo 720 SC)
products.details: Apply as a broad-spectrum protectant (FRAC M05) to protect against new infections.

products.name: Difenoconazole (e.g., CONCOR)
products.details: Systemic triazole fungicide (FRAC 3) used for curative and preventive action.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Alternaria.pathogen_timeline: Fungal spores are spread by air and dew runoff. High humidity and leaf wetness favor fruit infection.
prevention_tips: Thin trees to improve ventilation and sun penetration.
Remove infected crop debris and practice crop rotation/soil health management.
Use drip irrigation to avoid prolonged leaf wetness.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Healthy.description: The tree exhibits strong vigor, dense canopy, uniform growth, and high yield potential, demonstrating successful preventative measures and adequate nutrition.

organic_solution.strategy: Focus on continuous preventative nutritional and cultural management to maintain optimal health and pest resilience.

products.name: Activated Humic/Fulvic Acid
products.details: Fertilizer for crop nutrition, stress resistance, and root growth.

products.name: Bio-stimulant/Growth Regulator
products.details: Used to enhance yield and stress resistance (e.g., Katyayani Bhannaat).

chemical_solution.strategy: Implement a balanced NPK program with key micronutrients tailored to the flowering and fruiting stages.

products.name: Boron 20% EDTA Fertilizer
products.details: Crucial for flower and fruit setting; used to prevent flower and fruit drop.

products.name: Calcium Nitrate
products.details: Fertilizer used to support fruit development and quality.

Balanced Mangoo Dataset/Healthy.pathogen_timeline: N/A. Focus is on preventative nutrition and strong IPM to maintain resilience and minimize stress.
prevention_tips: Implement a strong integrated pest management (IPM) plan.
Rotate chemical controls with biological solutions for optimal results.
Monitor the orchard regularly for early signs of disease.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Leaf_Gall.disease_name: Leaf Gall (Lychee Erinose Mite - Aceria litchii)
Balanced Litchi Dataset/Leaf_Gall.description: Caused by a microscopic mite, this pest is characterized by the formation of reddish-brown, velvety, hairy galls (erinea) on the underside of young leaves. The leaves become thickened and curled, leading to premature leaf drop and reduced tree vigor.

organic_solution.strategy: Requires aggressive pruning of infested material and application of Sulphur or oil-based miticides to new growth flushes.

products.name: Surgical Pruning
products.details: Immediately remove and destroy (burn or bury) all infested leaves and branches to reduce the mite population.

products.name: Horticultural Oil / Dormant Oil
products.details: Apply oil sprays to suffocate overwintering mites. Apply during cooler parts of the day and ensure complete coverage of the leaf underside.

chemical_solution.strategy: Target new flushes with highly effective miticides in a strict rotational program (3 successive sprays at 10–14 day intervals are recommended).

products.name: Wettable Sulphur (e.g., Microthiol Disperss)
products.details: Effective chemical control, especially for new growth flushes. Apply twice at a 14-day interval after pruning.

products.name: Abamectin (e.g., Abamec 1.8 EC)
products.details: Highly effective acaricide (Group 6). Apply at the onset of new flushes to eliminate feeding mites.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Leaf_Gall.pathogen_timeline: The mite overwinters in the bark/buds and attacks only tender new growth (shoots, flowers, young fruit). The mites are protected once the gall (erineum) forms.
prevention_tips: Use only certified, mite-free planting material.
Ensure proper spacing to promote air circulation and reduce humidity.
Scout young leaves and the undersides of foliage regularly during the growing season.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Leaf_Blight.disease_name: Leaf Blight (Alternaria alternata and Colletotrichum gloeosporioides)
Balanced Litchi Dataset/Leaf_Blight.description: A complex of fungal diseases causing tip necrosis, leading to light brown to dark brown lesions that advance towards the leaf margins, eventually drying the leaves. It can also affect panicles and developing fruits.

organic_solution.strategy: Sanitation, moisture reduction, and preventative copper application.

products.name: Copper Oxychloride (0.1%)
products.details: Apply copper-based fungicides (FRAC M1) as a preventative spray.

products.name: Trichoderma/Antagonistic Microbes
products.details: Augment natural plant defense by soil application of beneficial microbes.

chemical_solution.strategy: Rotate protectants with systemic fungicides (Group 1, 3, or 11) to manage severity and resistance.

products.name: Mancozeb (0.15%)
products.details: Apply as a contact protectant (FRAC M03) to prevent disease spread.

products.name: Thiophanate Methyl (0.14%) or Difenoconazole (0.025%)
products.details: Systemic fungicides (FRAC 1 or 3) used for curative action if disease severity increases.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Leaf_Blight.pathogen_timeline: Most active during the warm and wet season. Fungi survive on fallen leaves and senescing leaves under the tree canopy.
prevention_tips: Remove weeds which act as alternative hosts for the pathogen.
Ensure proper plant spacing for adequate air circulation.
Prune diseased twigs and follow regular fungicidal spray schedules.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Healthy_Leaf.description: The foliage is uniformly colored, fully expanded, and free of blemishes, galls, or necrosis, reflecting successful preventative measures and balanced nutrition.

organic_solution.strategy: Maintain soil health and apply bio-nutrients to enhance leaf vitality and resistance to environmental stress.

products.name: Compost Tea / Bio-stimulant
products.details: Foliar or soil application to enhance plant immunity and vitality.

products.name: Pruning and Canopy Management
products.details: Post-harvest pruning to remove dead or weak shoots, encouraging new growth that will flower and fruit in the next season.

chemical_solution.strategy: Implement a balanced fertigation program, applying complex fertilizers immediately after harvest and pruning.

products.name: Complex NPK Fertilizer (e.g., 13:13:20:2)
products.details: Apply the complex fertilizer based on tree age immediately after harvest and pruning to support new shoot development.

products.name: Micronutrient Supplementation
products.details: Ensure adequate micronutrients (e.g., Zinc, Boron) to support healthy leaf emergence and prevent deficiency symptoms.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Healthy_Leaf.pathogen_timeline: N/A. Focus is on continuous preventative management and timely pruning/fertilization (post-harvest) to ensure next season's productivity.
prevention_tips: Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization, which can lead to dense growth that attracts pests.
Pruning should allow sunlight to penetrate the canopy and ease the application of crop-protectants.
Ensure sufficient air circulation around the trees.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Healthy.description: The tree exhibits strong vigor, balanced limbs, abundant new shoots after pruning, and high production potential.

organic_solution.strategy: Focus on post-harvest rejuvenation and soil enrichment to support the next season's growth cycle.

products.name: Neem Cake / Castor Cake
products.details: Apply bio-organic soil supplements along with recommended fertilizer doses.

products.name: Tree Rejuvenation
products.details: For old or non-productive trees, gradually head back the main limbs over two to three years to promote shoot formation and canopy renewal.

chemical_solution.strategy: Protecting all cut surfaces with a wound dressing or paint after pruning is essential for preventing the entry of fungi like *Diplodia* or *Fusarium*.

products.name: Tree Wound Dressing/Lead-free Paint
products.details: Protect all cut surfaces immediately after pruning to prevent pathogen entry.

products.name: Complex Fertilizer (Post-Rejuvenation)
products.details: Apply Sulphate of Ammonia and complex fertilizer after rejuvenation and water copiously.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Healthy.pathogen_timeline: N/A. Focus is on long-term management to maintain productivity, especially after harvest, which is when the tree prepares for the next flowering.
prevention_tips: Pruning should be done immediately after harvest, removing 25 to 30 cm of the fruit-bearing shoots.
Avoid too severe pruning, as it may lead to biennial bearing.
Irrigate copiously after fertilizer application during dry and hot conditions.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Fungal_Leaf_Spot.disease_name: Fungal Leaf Spot (Various Fungi - e.g., Phyllosticta spp., Phoma spp.)
Balanced Litchi Dataset/Fungal_Leaf_Spot.description: General category for fungal infections causing distinct, sometimes concentric, dark lesions on the leaves (e.g., Phyllosticta causes rounded, large, brownish-black spots with concentric ridges). Severe infections can lead to leaf shriveling or curling.

organic_solution.strategy: Sanitation and preventative Copper applications.

products.name: Copper Oxychloride (0.25%)
products.details: Apply copper-based sprays during the growing season to reduce fungal spread.

products.name: Pruning and Debris Removal
products.details: Remove and destroy infected and dead branches from time to time to control the spreading of infection.

chemical_solution.strategy: Targeted systemic fungicides used in rotation.

products.name: Thiophanate Methyl (0.15%) or Chlorothalonil (0.15%)
products.details: Apply effective systemic (FRAC 1) or contact (FRAC M05) fungicides during severe infestation.

products.name: Difenoconazole (0.05%)
products.details: Systemic DMI fungicide (FRAC 3) used for curative action.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Fungal_Leaf_Spot.pathogen_timeline: Infection can cause younger leaves to curl and older ones to shrivel. Continuous rain leads to more spreading of the disease.
prevention_tips: Improve air circulation through pruning and proper tree spacing.
Copper sulphate applied in spring can reduce disease spread.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Felt Leaf.disease_name: Felt Leaf (Lychee Erinose Mite - Aceria litchii)
Balanced Litchi Dataset/Felt Leaf.description: This is an alternative description for Leaf Gall. It refers to the **velvety fur** (felt-like patch, or erineum) that forms on the underside of young leaves as a result of the mite's feeding. The mites live and feed within this felt-like growth.

organic_solution.strategy: Same strategy as Leaf Gall: physical removal and cultural practices.

products.name: Neem Cake / Castor Cake
products.details: Soil application of these organic cakes provides nutritional support and helps manage mite incidence.

products.name: Pruning and Burning
products.details: Remove and destroy affected twigs by burning during June and November, which breaks the source of infestation.

chemical_solution.strategy: Apply miticides during flush emergence when mites migrate out of the felt to young leaves.

products.name: Fenazaquin (0.15%)
products.details: Acaricide used in combination with pruning and cake application for effective mite reduction during flush emergence.

products.name: Abamectin (e.g., Abamec 1.8 EC)
products.details: Effective chemical control targeting the mites when they are motile stages outside the erineum.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Felt Leaf.pathogen_timeline: The life cycle is about 14 days. Sprays must be timed at 14-day intervals after the first spray on new leaves to ensure control of newly hatched mites.
prevention_tips: Avoid nursery plants taken from infested trees.
The combination of pruning, cake application, and miticide spray is superior to chemical application alone.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Dry Leaf.disease_name: Dry Leaf / Leaf Necrosis (Colletotrichum gloeosporioides / Alternaria alternata)
Balanced Litchi Dataset/Dry Leaf.description: Leaf tip withering and browning, leading to the drying up and shedding of leaves. Can be confused with leaf burn from hot weather but is caused by fungal pathogens.

organic_solution.strategy: Pruning of infected material and use of preventative copper sprays.

products.name: Sanitation and Pruning
products.details: Prune diseased twigs and immediately remove dead or infected leaves from the orchard floor to reduce inoculum.

products.name: Copper Oxychloride (0.25%)
products.details: Apply copper-based sprays during severe infestation to control the fungal spread.

chemical_solution.strategy: Systemic fungicides are used in rotation to protect new growth and achieve curative action.

products.name: Difenoconazole (0.05%) or Thiophanate Methyl (0.15%)
products.details: Apply systemic fungicides (FRAC 3 or 1) during severe infestation for curative action.

products.name: Azoxystrobin (0.023%)
products.details: Apply QoI fungicide (FRAC 11) for broad-spectrum fungal control.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Dry Leaf.pathogen_timeline: Damage occurs during August-September and January-February. The fungus can enter through insect feeding or mechanical injuries.
prevention_tips: Pruning should be done carefully to ensure complete eradication of the pathogen.
Avoid drought and other physiological stress, as they can lead to dieback.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Deficiency Leaf.description: Leaf discoloration (yellowing, bronzing, marginal burn) or malformation not caused by pests or pathogens. Often related to deficiencies in key nutrients like Zinc, Boron, or Iron, or poor soil pH/drainage.

organic_solution.strategy: Improve soil health, drainage, and apply organic, balanced nutrition.

products.name: Chelated Micronutrients (Foliar)
products.details: Apply foliar sprays of chelated macro and micro-elements, focusing on Iron and Zinc for young leaf issues.

products.name: Compost / Bio-stimulant
products.details: Regularly incorporate organic matter and compost to improve soil structure and nutrient availability.

chemical_solution.strategy: Implement soil and foliar fertilizer programs based on soil and tissue analysis.

products.name: Complex NPK Fertilizer (e.g., 13:13:20:2)
products.details: Apply complex fertilizer based on tree age and canopy size, particularly immediately after harvest.

products.name: Water-Soluble Micronutrient Mix
products.details: Apply a full range of micro-nutrients via fertigation or soil drenching.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Deficiency Leaf.pathogen_timeline: N/A. Deficiencies are chronic problems related to ongoing tree nutrition or soil conditions (e.g., high pH limiting iron uptake).
prevention_tips: Conduct soil and leaf tissue testing annually to detect hidden deficiencies.
Ensure proper irrigation to prevent water stress, which hinders nutrient uptake.
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilization, which can attract pests and induce deficiencies.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Curl Leaf.description: Abnormal leaf growth and curling, often resulting in small, distorted, or cupped leaves. This can be a symptom of severe **Lychee Erinose Mite (LEM)** infestation, nutrient deficiency, or virus infection (though viruses are less common).

organic_solution.strategy: If mites are confirmed, follow the strategy for Leaf Gall/Felt Leaf (pruning and oil sprays).

products.name: Hirsutella thompsonii (Bio-control)
products.details: A beneficial fungal ally effective against mites. Apply during periods of high humidity.

products.name: Pruning and Sanitation
products.details: Remove and destroy severely affected shoots and leaves.

chemical_solution.strategy: If mites are the cause, use miticides. If chemical damage or nutrient issue, correct the underlying cause.

products.name: Abamectin (e.g., Abamec 1.8 EC)
products.details: Effective chemical control against the Lychee Erinose Mite.

products.name: Wettable Sulphur
products.details: Recommended for Lychee Erinose Mite treatment.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Curl Leaf.pathogen_timeline: Curling from mites occurs on tender new growth. Damage should be treated immediately upon emergence of the new flush.
prevention_tips: Regularly thin out emerging shoots to ensure branches are well positioned and reduce dense growth.
Ensure adequate micronutrient levels through fertilization.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Bituminous Leaf.description: Lichen is not a disease but a symbiotic composite of algae and fungi that colonizes the plant surface. It can resemble black mold or create rough, bark-like lesions (Corky Bark) that mainly affect aesthetics and photosynthesis if covering extensive areas.

organic_solution.strategy: Improve tree vigor and airflow. The presence of lichens often indicates a tree under stress or in a dense, humid environment.

products.name: Copper Oxychloride/Bordeaux Mixture
products.details: Applied as a fungicide to suppress the fungal component of the lichen.

products.name: Pruning for Ventilation
products.details: Prune to increase sunlight and air penetration, discouraging lichen growth, which prefers shaded, humid surfaces.

chemical_solution.strategy: Apply fungicides that control the growth of the fungal component, often following pruning.

products.name: Dormant Oil Spray
products.details: Application of horticultural oil can help loosen lichen/moss on branches for easier physical removal (applied when the tree is dormant).

products.name: Copper Sulphate
products.details: Copper sulphate applied in spring can reduce the spread of fungal growth.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Bituminous Leaf.pathogen_timeline: Lichen is a slow-growing organism, and its presence is a sign of long-term tree health or environmental issues.
prevention_tips: Maintain tree vigor and avoid excessive moss or lichen coverage.
Prune regularly to encourage development of a compact canopy that favors sunlight penetration.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Anthrax Leaf.description: Anthracnose is a major fungal disease in Litchi. On leaves, it causes leaf necrosis, often merging with other lesions, and is a significant source of inoculum for flower and fruit infection.

organic_solution.strategy: Sanitation and preventative Copper barrier sprays are crucial.

products.name: Copper Oxychloride (0.25%)
products.details: Apply copper-based fungicides during severe infestation to control the fungal spread.

products.name: Pruning of Dead Wood
products.details: Prune dead wood and remove infected leaves/twigs to reduce inoculum incidence.

chemical_solution.strategy: Rotate between contact and systemic fungicides, especially during flowering, to protect the whole tree.

products.name: Carbendazim (0.1%)
products.details: Apply systemic fungicide (FRAC 1) after panicle initiation and at the color-break stage of fruits.

products.name: Azoxystrobin (0.023%) or Thiophanate Methyl (0.14%)
products.details: Use systemic fungicides (FRAC 11 or 1) for broad-spectrum fungal control.

Balanced Litchi Dataset/Anthrax Leaf.pathogen_timeline: The pathogen is the same one that causes panicle/fruit blight. The first spray should be just after panicle initiation (before flower opening).
prevention_tips: Orchard hygiene (pruning dead wood and removing infected debris) helps reduce disease incidence.
Ensure sufficient soil moisture by sprinkling water or light irrigation after applying bio-control agents.

Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Infestation Th.description: Thrips are tiny, slender insects that feed on the leaf surface and flower parts, causing silvering, stippling, or bronzing of leaves and scarring of the fruit. They also act as the vector for important viruses like Tomato Spotted Wilt Virus (TSWV).

organic_solution.strategy: Requires strict sanitation and rotation between contact sprays and bio-pesticides, focusing on covering the underside of leaves.

products.name: Neem Oil / Insecticidal Soap
products.details: Apply frequently (every 5-7 days) with high coverage to suppress thrips populations.

products.name: Blue/Yellow Sticky Traps
products.details: Use colored sticky traps for monitoring and mass trapping of adults in the field or protected structures.

chemical_solution.strategy: Rotation is mandatory to manage resistance. Use targeted insecticides (Groups 5, 4, 3) and aim for high spray volume to reach feeding sites.

products.name: Spinosad (e.g., Tracer)
products.details: Biological-derived insecticide (Group 5) highly effective against thrips. Use in alternation.

products.name: Acetamiprid or Thiamethoxam
products.details: Systemic neonicotinoids (Group 4A) used as drench or foliar spray to control sucking pests and virus vectors.

Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Infestation Th.pathogen_timeline: Thrips thrive in hot, dry weather. Monitoring and treatment must be continuous, especially from the flowering stage onward.
prevention_tips: Remove weeds, which can serve as alternative hosts for thrips.
Use reflective mulch to deter thrips during early growth stages.
Ensure proper irrigation to avoid water-stressed plants, which are more attractive to thrips.

Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Epilachna beet.disease_name: Epilachna Beetle Infestation (Epilachna vigintioctopunctata - Spotted Cucumber Beetle)
Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Epilachna beet.description: Both the bright yellow larvae (spiny, segmented) and the adult beetles feed on the underside of leaves, leaving behind characteristic lace-like or skeletonized leaves. Severe damage reduces photosynthesis and yield.

organic_solution.strategy: Manual collection and application of specific microbial bio-pesticides.

products.name: Manual Collection/Physical Removal
products.details: Regularly patrol the field and hand-pick the adults, larvae, and egg masses. Drop them into soapy water.

products.name: Neem Oil / Pyrethrins
products.details: Apply botanical insecticides as a contact spray targeting all life stages, ensuring coverage on the underside of leaves.

chemical_solution.strategy: Use effective contact/systemic insecticides, aiming to control both adults and feeding larvae. Rotation is important.

products.name: Lambda-Cyhalothrin (e.g., Attack-CS)
products.details: Fast-acting pyrethroid (Group 3A) for knockdown of adults and larvae upon sighting.

products.name: Chlorpyrifos (e.g., CHLORO20)
products.details: Organophosphate (Group 1B) insecticide used for broad chewing pest control (per local regulation).

Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Epilachna beet.pathogen_timeline: Beetles are active throughout the growing season, with multiple generations possible. Control is needed immediately upon reaching threshold levels.
prevention_tips: Rotate crops and destroy crop debris immediately after harvest to disrupt the life cycle.
Cover crops (like mustard) can be used as a trap crop to attract beetles away from the main field.

Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Eggplant Mosai.description: A viral disease causing leaf mosaic (mottled light and dark green patterns), leaf distortion, and severe stunting of the plant. Infected plants produce poor-quality or no fruit. Spread primarily by **Aphids** or through mechanical means. **No cure.**

organic_solution.strategy: Strict sanitation, immediate roguing (removal of infected plants), and vector control.

products.name: Mineral Oil
products.details: Apply foliar sprays to disrupt aphid transmission and feeding behavior.

products.name: Sanitation (Tool Cleaning)
products.details: Clean pruning tools with a 10% bleach solution after handling any suspicious plant to prevent mechanical spread.

chemical_solution.strategy: Focus entirely on systemic insecticides to control aphid vectors and prevent virus transmission.

products.name: Imidacloprid (e.g., Confidor)
products.details: Systemic neonicotinoid (Group 4A) used for sucking pest control.

products.name: Flonicamid (e.g., Strangle)
products.details: Specific aphicide (IRAC 29) for excellent knockdown control. Use in rotation with Group 4A products.

Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Eggplant Mosai.pathogen_timeline: No cure. Symptoms develop after inoculation. Immediate removal and destruction of symptomatic plants is the only way to stop local spread.
prevention_tips: Use certified virus-free seedlings.
Immediately rogue and destroy any plant showing mosaic symptoms.
Control weeds that may harbor the virus or aphid vectors.

Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Caterpillars.disease_name: Caterpillars (Lepidoptera Larvae - e.g., Shoot and Fruit Borer)
Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Caterpillars.description: Larvae of various moth species (e.g., Leucinodes or Plusiinae) that feed on leaves, burrow into stems (causing wilting), or tunnel into the fruit (Fruit Borer), making them unmarketable. This is the most damaging pest for eggplant fruit.

organic_solution.strategy: Cultural practices, manual destruction of infested parts, and use of specific biological controls.

products.name: Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt)
products.details: Specific microbial pesticide (NC) highly effective against moth larvae. Must be ingested, so ensure good coverage on feeding areas.

products.name: Pheromone Traps
products.details: Use traps containing species-specific pheromones to monitor and mass-trap adult male moths, reducing future breeding.

chemical_solution.strategy: Apply broad-spectrum or selective insecticides targeted at the larval stage before they bore into stems/fruit. Rotation of groups (e.g., 5, 6, 28) is essential.

products.name: Emamectin Benzoate
products.details: Highly effective non-systemic insecticide (Group 6) for caterpillar and borer control. Use in rotation.

products.name: Chlorantraniliprole (e.g., Coragen)
products.details: Anthranilic diamide (Group 28) with a long residual effect against borers and a favorable safety profile for beneficials.

Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Caterpillars.pathogen_timeline: Damage occurs continuously once the plant starts setting fruit. Control measures must be applied protectively during this stage.
prevention_tips: Prune and destroy borer-infested shoots and fruits immediately (roguing).
Bag developing fruit to provide a physical barrier against borers.
Avoid excess nitrogen, which promotes soft, tender growth favored by borers.

Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Blight Fungal.disease_name: Fungal Blight Complex (Phomopsis Blight/Fruit Rot, Alternaria Leaf Spot)
Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Blight Fungal.description: Fungal complex causing **Phomopsis** (grey/brown lesions on leaves, cankers on stem, and soft, depressed, light brown fruit rot) and **Alternaria** (dark, concentric 'bullseye' spots on leaves). Both thrive in wet, warm conditions.

organic_solution.strategy: Sanitation, crop rotation, and preventative copper-based treatments.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide (Preventative)
products.details: Apply copper-based fungicides (FRAC M1) as a protective barrier, especially before expected rain events.

products.name: Crop Rotation and Sanitation
products.details: Practice long rotation (3+ years) and destroy crop debris completely, as the fungi survive on old plant material.

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires a strong rotation between protectants (M) and effective systemic fungicides (Groups 3 and 11) to manage both diseases.

products.name: Chlorothalonil (e.g., Bravo 720 SC)
products.details: Apply as a broad-spectrum contact protectant (FRAC M05).

products.name: Azoxystrobin (e.g., Ortiva) or Difenoconazole (e.g., Score)
products.details: Alternate with systemic fungicides (FRAC 11 or 3) for curative action and resistance management.

Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Blight Fungal.pathogen_timeline: Infections are most severe when temperatures are warm and foliage remains wet. Fungicides should be applied preventatively, starting before the first expected symptoms.
prevention_tips: Use certified disease-free seed, as Phomopsis can be seed-borne.
Avoid overhead irrigation, which promotes prolonged leaf wetness.
Ensure proper pruning and staking to improve air circulation.

Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Healthy.description: The plant exhibits strong vigor, deep green, blemish-free foliage, strong branching, and high yield potential, demonstrating successful preventative measures and adequate nutrition.

organic_solution.strategy: Focus on continuous preventative nutritional and cultural management to maintain optimal health and pest resilience.

products.name: Compost Tea / Bio-stimulant
products.details: Foliar or soil application to promote beneficial microbial activity and enhance plant vitality.

products.name: Pruning and Staking
products.details: Properly stake the plants and prune lower leaves to improve air circulation and reduce soil splash.

chemical_solution.strategy: Implement a balanced NPK program with key micronutrients tailored to the continuous fruiting nature of eggplant.

products.name: Balanced NPK Fertilizer (e.g., 20-20-20)
products.details: Use a complete NPK fertilizer program adjusted for the fruiting phase (higher K).

products.name: Calcium/Boron Foliar Spray
products.details: Apply during the fruiting stage to support cell wall strength and fruit quality.

Balanced Eggplant Dataset/Healthy.pathogen_timeline: N/A. Focus is on preventative nutrition and strong IPM to maintain resilience and high yield.
prevention_tips: Implement a strong integrated pest management (IPM) plan.
Rotate crops to break disease cycles.
Monitor fields regularly for early signs of borers and viral vectors.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Pythium Fruit.description: An Oomycete (water mold) disease causing soft, water-soaked lesions on the side of the fruit resting on the wet soil, often developing a white, cottony fungal growth (mycelium). It is a soil-borne pathogen favored by warm, saturated soils and high humidity.

organic_solution.strategy: Cultural control is paramount: avoid soil contact and improve drainage to eliminate water-saturated conditions.

products.name: Mulching / Trellising
products.details: Use plastic mulch or trellising to lift the fruit off the wet soil surface, preventing direct contact with the pathogen.

products.name: Soil Solarization
products.details: Cover wet soil with clear plastic in the summer to heat the soil and kill Oomycete resting spores (oospores).

chemical_solution.strategy: Requires the use of specific Oomycete fungicides (Group 4 and 33) applied as soil drenches or through the irrigation system early in the season.

products.name: Propamocarb (e.g., Previcur Energy)
products.details: Systemic fungicide (Group 28) used as a soil drench or through drip irrigation to control soil-borne Oomycetes.

products.name: Phosphites (e.g., Phostrol)
products.details: Systemic fungicide (Group 33) effective against Oomycetes, applied preventatively through irrigation or foliar spray.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Pythium Fruit.pathogen_timeline: Infection is triggered by high soil moisture and warm temperatures. It causes rapid fruit decay and thrives under wet field conditions.
prevention_tips: Use drip irrigation instead of furrow/overhead irrigation to keep the fruit dry.
Plant in raised beds or use trellising/mulch to keep fruit away from the soil.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Gummy Stem Bli.description: A serious fungal disease causing leaf spots (circular, brown, water-soaked), stem cankers (with characteristic brownish, sticky 'gum' exudate), and internal stem rot. It is often confused with Black Rot of the fruit, causing dark, sunken lesions.

organic_solution.strategy: Sanitation, use of tolerant varieties, and preventative copper application during high-risk periods.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide (Preventative)
products.details: Apply copper-based fungicides (FRAC M1) as a protective barrier when conditions are favorable for disease spread.

products.name: Pruning and Sanitation
products.details: Remove and destroy infected leaves, stems, and fruits promptly. Sterilize tools (10% bleach) after handling infected plants.

chemical_solution.strategy: Aggressive rotation of systemic (Group 1, 3, 11) and protective (M) fungicides, starting preventatively, especially in greenhouse settings.

products.name: Chlorothalonil (e.g., Bravo 720 SC)
products.details: Apply as a broad-spectrum contact protectant (FRAC M05) to protect new growth.

products.name: Difenoconazole (e.g., Score 250 EC)
products.details: Systemic DMI fungicide (FRAC 3) for curative and protective action. Alternate strictly with M05.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Gummy Stem Bli.pathogen_timeline: Fungus survives on crop debris for up to two years. High humidity and leaf wetness are required for spore germination. Infection can be latent (hidden) in fruit, causing storage rot.
prevention_tips: Practice a long crop rotation (2-3 years) with non-cucurbit crops.
Use certified disease-free seed.
Ensure proper ventilation in greenhouses to reduce humidity.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Downy Mildew.description: A highly aggressive Oomycete disease causing angular, water-soaked, yellow lesions on the upper leaf surface with corresponding purplish-gray spores on the underside. Leads to rapid defoliation and plant collapse.

organic_solution.strategy: Requires rigorous sanitation and proactive application of copper-based treatments to sterilize foliage.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide (e.g., Kocide, Champion)
products.details: Protective contact fungicide (FRAC M1) applied at tight intervals (5-7 days) for Oomycetes.

products.name: Peroxide/Peracetic Acid (ZeroTol/OxiDate)
products.details: Peroxide-based cleaner useful in killing surface spores and reducing inoculum.

chemical_solution.strategy: Use fungicide mixtures that combine systemic and protective MoAs, alternating chemical groups (4, 40, 11, M5) for full protection against explosive spread.

products.name: Metalaxyl-M + Chlorothalonil (e.g., Ridomil Gold)
products.details: Combination of systemic Phenylamide (FRAC 4) and protective Nitrile (FRAC M5). Highly curative.

products.name: Dimethomorph + Mancozeb (Acrobat MZ)
products.details: Systemic Cinnamic acid (FRAC 40) + multi-site Dithiocarbamate (FRAC M3) pre-mix. Highly effective Oomycete specific control.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Downy Mildew.pathogen_timeline: URGENT. Capable of plant collapse in days. Immediate application of systemic and contact fungicides is crucial to stop explosive spread, especially when cool and wet.
prevention_tips: Avoid late-day watering that keeps leaves wet overnight.
Use resistant or tolerant cucumber varieties.
Ensure maximum ventilation to reduce leaf wetness.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Belly Rot.description: A soil-borne fungal disease causing a sunken, dark brown, or black lesion on the side of the fruit that contacts the soil. The lesion remains firm and can destroy the marketable portion of the fruit.

organic_solution.strategy: Cultural control is paramount: avoid soil contact and improve soil health with biological suppressants.

products.name: Mulching / Trellising
products.details: Use mulch (e.g., straw, plastic) or trellising to lift the fruit off the wet soil surface.

products.name: Trichoderma fungus-based biopesticides
products.details: Apply *Trichoderma* as a soil drench or seed treatment to suppress *Rhizoctonia* in the soil.

chemical_solution.strategy: Target the soil-borne pathogen using in-furrow or seed treatments, often using the SDHI (Group 7) fungicides.

products.name: Azoxystrobin (In-Furrow)
products.details: Apply QoI fungicide (FRAC 11) in the furrow at planting to control the progression of the fungus in the soil.

products.name: Fludioxonil (Seed Treatment)
products.details: Phenylpyrrole fungicide (FRAC 12) used as a seed or transplant dip to control initial infection.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Belly Rot.pathogen_timeline: Infection occurs when fruit touches wet, contaminated soil. Control is preventative and soil-focused, as lesions cannot be cured.
prevention_tips: Use only disease-free seed.
Avoid planting in fields with a history of *Rhizoctonia* diseases.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Bacterial Wilt.description: A bacterial disease causing sudden, permanent wilting of individual leaves or entire vines, without yellowing. It clogs the vascular system (xylem). It is transmitted **exclusively by the Striped or Spotted Cucumber Beetle**.

organic_solution.strategy: Strictly focus on controlling the cucumber beetle vector and immediate removal of infected plants.

products.name: Row Covers / Fine Netting
products.details: Use fine netting immediately after planting to exclude cucumber beetles before they infect the crop.

products.name: Pyrethrins / Neem Oil
products.details: Apply botanical insecticides frequently to suppress beetle activity (contact control).

chemical_solution.strategy: No chemical treatment is effective against the bacteria inside the plant; focus is 100% on insecticide application to kill the cucumber beetle vector.

products.name: Imidacloprid (e.g., Confidor)
products.details: Systemic neonicotinoid (Group 4A) applied as a soil drench or seed treatment to protect the plant from early season beetle feeding.

products.name: Lambda-Cyhalothrin (e.g., Attack-CS)
products.details: Fast-acting pyrethroid (Group 3A) for knockdown of adult beetles upon sighting.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Bacterial Wilt.pathogen_timeline: Once the bacteria enter the plant, wilting is permanent and rapid. The only way to stop the disease is to eliminate the beetle vector before it feeds.
prevention_tips: Immediately rogue and destroy any wilted plants (bacteria are inside the vine).
Control volunteer cucurbits, which harbor the bacteria and the beetle vector.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Anthracnose.description: Fungal disease causing angular, dark lesions on leaves, often starting at the margin. On fruit, it causes circular, sunken, black spots with pinkish ooze. Thrives in warm, humid conditions.

organic_solution.strategy: Sanitation and preventative Copper barrier sprays are crucial.

products.name: Copper Hydroxide (Preventative)
products.details: Apply copper-based fungicides (FRAC M1) as a protective barrier when conditions are favorable for disease.

products.name: Crop Rotation and Debris Removal
products.details: Practice crop rotation (2-3 years) and destroy crop debris completely to reduce inoculum.

chemical_solution.strategy: Rotate between broad-spectrum protectants and systemic fungicides (Group 3 or 11) to manage the disease on foliage and fruit.

products.name: Mancozeb (e.g., Dithane M45)
products.details: Apply as a contact protectant (FRAC M03) every 7-10 days, essential for resistance management.

products.name: Azoxystrobin (e.g., Ortiva 250 SC)
products.details: Alternate with a systemic QoI fungicide (FRAC 11) for curative action.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Anthracnose.pathogen_timeline: Fungus survives on infected seeds and plant debris. Spread is rapid with rain splash and favored by warm, moist conditions.
prevention_tips: Use certified disease-free seed.
Avoid overhead irrigation, which spreads spores.
Ensure proper ventilation to reduce leaf wetness duration.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Fresh Cucumber.description: This status refers to the cucumber fruit being harvested at optimal maturity, free from blemishes, mechanical damage, or pathogen infection, ensuring high market value and long shelf life.

organic_solution.strategy: Focus on optimal irrigation, harvest timing, and gentle handling to maintain quality.

products.name: Gentle Harvesting/Culling
products.details: Harvest during the cooler part of the day and cull any damaged or deformed fruit in the field immediately.

products.name: Washing and Cooling
products.details: Wash fruit immediately after harvest in cool, clean water to remove field heat and reduce microbial load before packing.

chemical_solution.strategy: Post-harvest use of approved disinfectants (e.g., chlorine wash) for washing water to maintain hygiene.

products.name: Chlorine/Sanitizer Wash
products.details: Use a food-grade sanitizer (e.g., sodium hypochlorite) in the washing water to minimize post-harvest microbial rot.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Fresh Cucumber.pathogen_timeline: Quality assurance is continuous from field management to packaging. Post-harvest rot occurs rapidly if the fruit is damaged or contaminated.
prevention_tips: Avoid handling fruit when wet.
Minimize the time between harvest and cooling/packing.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Healthy.description: The plant exhibits strong vigor, dense canopy, dark green, blemish-free foliage, and high yield potential, demonstrating successful preventative measures and adequate nutrition.

organic_solution.strategy: Focus on continuous preventative nutritional and cultural management to maintain optimal health and resilience.

products.name: Compost Tea / Bio-stimulant
products.details: Foliar or soil application to promote beneficial microbial activity and enhance plant vitality.

products.name: Trekkers and Pruning
products.details: Use trellising (vertical support) and prune lower, older leaves to improve air circulation and reduce soil-borne pathogen splash.

chemical_solution.strategy: Implement a balanced fertigation program tailored to the cucumber growth stage (heavy feeder during fruiting).

products.name: High Potassium NPK Fertilizer
products.details: Use a formula with high Potassium (K) and Calcium during the fruiting phase to ensure strong fruit quality and shelf life.

products.name: Calcium/Boron Foliar Spray
products.details: Apply during the flowering/fruiting stage to support fruit development and prevent quality issues.

Balanced Cucumber Dataset/Healthy.pathogen_timeline: N/A. Focus is on continuous preventative nutrition and strong IPM to maintain resilience and high yield.
prevention_tips: Implement a strong integrated pest management (IPM) plan.
Rotate crops to break disease cycles.
Monitor fields regularly for early signs of downy mildew and wilt.

Balanced Banana Dataset/sigatoka.description: The most common and widespread banana leaf disease. Starts as small, reddish-brown streaks that develop into elliptical spots with grey centers and dark borders. Causes premature death of leaves, reducing the plant's photosynthetic capacity and leading to premature fruit ripening and yield loss.

organic_solution.strategy: Cultural control (de-suckering, de-leafing) is essential, combined with preventative organic treatments to protect young, emerging leaves.

products.name: De-suckering and De-leafing
products.details: Remove old, diseased leaves (pruning) and ensure proper plant density (de-suckering) to improve air circulation and reduce humidity.

products.name: Horticultural Oil (Mineral Oil)
products.details: Apply mineral oil (or oil/water emulsions) every 10–14 days to newly emerged leaves to inhibit spore germination.

chemical_solution.strategy: A strict fungicide rotation program is mandatory, using systemic fungicides (DMIs, QoIs) in mixtures or in alternation with broad-spectrum protectants (Mancozeb) to prevent resistance.

products.name: Propiconazole (e.g., Tilt)
products.details: Systemic DMI fungicide (Group 3). Apply in rotation every 10–14 days, often in a mixture with mineral oil.

products.name: Mancozeb (e.g., Dithane M45)
products.details: Broad-spectrum contact fungicide (FRAC M03) always used in combination or rotation with systemics for resistance management.

Balanced Banana Dataset/sigatoka.pathogen_timeline: New leaves are susceptible when unfurling. The incubation period is 10–14 days. Fungicides must be applied protectively and regularly to the new, emerging leaves.
prevention_tips: Plant resistant varieties where possible.
Ensure proper drainage to reduce humidity and soil moisture.
Maintain a strong plant-to-plant control (de-suckering) to improve airflow.

Balanced Banana Dataset/pestalotiopsis.description: A fungal leaf spot, often found on older, stressed, or senescing leaves. It causes circular to elliptical spots, often with a grayish-white center and a dark border. Less critical than Sigatoka but reduces overall leaf area.

organic_solution.strategy: Improve general plant health and remove infected material. Often controlled by treatments aimed at Sigatoka.

products.name: Copper Oxychloride (Preventative)
products.details: Apply copper-based fungicides (FRAC M1) as a general protective spray against minor leaf pathogens.

products.name: Balanced Nutrition
products.details: Ensure adequate nutrition and water management to reduce plant stress and increase natural resistance.

chemical_solution.strategy: Typically managed by the same broad-spectrum fungicides used for Sigatoka control (Mancozeb or Chlorothalonil).

products.name: Chlorothalonil (e.g., Bravo 720 SC)
products.details: Apply as a broad-spectrum contact protectant (FRAC M05).

products.name: Azoxystrobin (e.g., Ortiva 250 SC)
products.details: Systemic QoI fungicide (FRAC 11), used in rotation for major fungal leaf diseases.

Balanced Banana Dataset/pestalotiopsis.pathogen_timeline: Fungus survives on dead leaves and debris. Infections occur during warm, wet periods. Control is preventative.
prevention_tips: Keep the plantation floor clean of dead plant debris and old leaves.
Improve air circulation to reduce humidity within the canopy.

Balanced Banana Dataset/Panama Wilt Dise.disease_name: Panama Wilt / Fusarium Wilt (Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense - Foc)
Balanced Banana Dataset/Panama Wilt Dise.description: A lethal soil-borne fungal disease that enters through roots, clogging the vascular system (xylem). Symptoms include severe yellowing and wilting of older leaves (starting from the edges), and eventually, the plant stem splits and dies. **No effective chemical cure exists.**

organic_solution.strategy: Exclusion, sanitation, and use of resistant/tolerant varieties are the only control methods for this devastating disease.

products.name: Quarantine and Destruction
products.details: Immediately remove and destroy (bury or burn) infected plants. The area should be fenced off and quarantined to prevent spread.

products.name: Trichoderma fungus-based biopesticides
products.details: Applying antagonistic fungi (*Trichoderma* spp.) to the soil can suppress the survival and spread of *Fusarium* spores.

chemical_solution.strategy: No fungicides can cure an infected plant. The focus is strictly on using clean planting material and avoiding disease-prone areas.

products.name: Certified Tissue Culture Plantlets
products.details: The most vital chemical/preventative measure is planting laboratory-tested, Foc-free plantlets (tissue culture).

products.name: Soil pH Management (Liming)
products.details: Managing soil pH (liming) to a higher level (around pH 6.0–7.0) can help reduce the severity of the disease in some cases.

Balanced Banana Dataset/Panama Wilt Dise.pathogen_timeline: Fungus survives in the soil for decades. Spread is mechanical (tools, water runoff, infected suckers). Symptoms can take months to appear after infection.
prevention_tips: Use only certified, clean tissue culture plants.
Restrict movement of equipment, soil, and water from infected areas.
Avoid planting susceptible cultivars (e.g., Gros Michel).

Balanced Banana Dataset/Healthy Banana.description: The plant exhibits strong vigor, erect leaves free of fungal spots, uniform bunch development, and high yield potential, demonstrating successful preventative measures and adequate nutrition.

organic_solution.strategy: Focus on continuous sanitation, maintenance of airflow, and soil enrichment.

products.name: Compost Tea / Bio-stimulant
products.details: Foliar or soil application to promote beneficial microbial activity and enhance plant vitality.

products.name: De-suckering and Propping
products.details: Maintain proper density (one large mother plant, one follower, one child) and use propping to support heavy bunches and prevent lodging.

chemical_solution.strategy: Implement a balanced fertigation program, particularly ensuring high Potassium (K) input for bunch quality and weight.

products.name: High Potassium NPK Fertilizer
products.details: Use a formula with high K and sufficient Magnesium/Boron to ensure bunch development and prevent splitting/poor filling.

products.name: Mineral Oil Spray (Preventative)
products.details: Regular preventative mineral oil sprays to protect the young emerging leaf and reduce the risk of Sigatoka spore germination.

Balanced Banana Dataset/Healthy Banana.pathogen_timeline: N/A. Focus is on continuous preventative nutrition and strong IPM to maintain resilience and high yield.
prevention_tips: Plant certified, disease-free tissue culture plantlets.
Ensure proper irrigation, avoiding water stress during bunch filling.
Maintain a continuous canopy rotation (de-suckering/follower selection).

Balanced Banana Dataset/cordana.description: A minor fungal leaf spot, often appearing as large, oval, light brown spots surrounded by a bright yellow halo. It usually follows a primary Sigatoka infection, appearing on the margins of Sigatoka lesions.

organic_solution.strategy: Improve general tree health and sanitation. Cordana is typically controlled by treatments aimed at Sigatoka.

products.name: De-leafing and Sanitation
products.details: Remove severely infected leaves (de-leafing) to reduce inoculum in the plantation.

products.name: Copper Oxychloride (Preventative)
products.details: Apply copper-based fungicides (FRAC M1) as a general protective spray.

chemical_solution.strategy: The same broad-spectrum protectant fungicides used for Sigatoka are effective (Mancozeb or Chlorothalonil).

products.name: Mancozeb (e.g., Dithane M45)
products.details: Apply broad-spectrum contact fungicide (FRAC M03) every 10–14 days as part of the Sigatoka spray schedule.

products.name: Chlorothalonil (e.g., Bravo 720 SC)
products.details: Apply broad-spectrum contact protectant (FRAC M05) in alternation with Mancozeb.

Balanced Banana Dataset/cordana.pathogen_timeline: Typically appears secondary to other leaf spots or on stressed plants. The disease is controlled by standard cultural practices and fungicide rotations for Sigatoka.
prevention_tips: Maintain tree vigor and avoid environmental stress.
Follow the recommended spray schedule for Sigatoka diseases.

Balanced Banana Dataset/Black and Yellow.description: More aggressive than Yellow Sigatoka. Starts as dark, reddish-brown streaks that rapidly turn into black, elliptical spots. Causes more severe and rapid leaf area destruction, leading to complete premature defoliation and major yield loss. Fungicides are critical.

organic_solution.strategy: Cultural control and sanitation are crucial due to the disease's high aggressiveness.

products.name: Oil-based Fungicide Emulsion
products.details: Mineral oil or a mixture of oil and water applied frequently to new leaves (as often as every 7–10 days).

products.name: De-leafing and De-trashing
products.details: Aggressive removal of all symptomatic leaves and dead trash to physically remove inoculum source, reducing the required spray frequency.

chemical_solution.strategy: Intense, scheduled rotation of systemic fungicides (DMIs, QoIs) in combination with broad-spectrum protectants (Mancozeb) is essential for control and preventing fungicide resistance.

products.name: Azoxystrobin (e.g., Ortiva 250 SC) + Mancozeb
products.details: Combination of systemic QoI (FRAC 11) and protectant (M03). QoIs should never be used alone due to high resistance risk.

products.name: Difenoconazole (e.g., Score 250 EC)
products.details: Systemic DMI fungicide (Group 3). Alternate with the QoI group (Group 11) to manage resistance.

Balanced Banana Dataset/Black and Yellow.pathogen_timeline: Black Sigatoka has a shorter incubation period (7–10 days) and causes more damage than Yellow Sigatoka. Spray cycles are often reduced to 7 days during peak humidity.
prevention_tips: Follow fungicide application intervals strictly to prevent spore production.
Use weather-based forecasting models to optimize the timing of fungicide applications.
Ensure new leaves are sprayed immediately upon emergence.

Balanced Banana Dataset/Chewing insect d.description: Damage caused by caterpillars (larvae of moths or butterflies, like the Skipper) that chew on the leaf margins or roll the leaves to feed inside, causing ragged or shredded leaf edges and reduced photosynthetic area.

organic_solution.strategy: Manual removal of damaged material and use of highly selective microbial bio-pesticides.

products.name: Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt)
products.details: Specific microbial pesticide (NC) highly effective against chewing larvae/caterpillars. Must be ingested, so apply to active feeding areas.

products.name: Sanitation and Removal
products.details: Manually crush or remove larvae found inside rolled leaves. De-leaf damaged foliage to reduce hiding spots.

chemical_solution.strategy: Use selective or broad-spectrum insecticides based on the economic damage threshold. Target the early larval stages.

products.name: Emamectin Benzoate
products.details: Highly effective non-systemic insecticide (Group 6) for caterpillar control. Use in rotation.

products.name: Lambda-Cyhalothrin (e.g., Attack-CS)
products.details: Fast-acting pyrethroid (Group 3A) for knockdown of severe caterpillar infestations.

Balanced Banana Dataset/Chewing insect d.pathogen_timeline: Damage is continuous during the growing season. New leaves are most susceptible. Control must be timely to prevent damage to the three youngest leaves.
prevention_tips: Regularly monitor plants for rolled leaves or fresh chewing damage.
Ensure proper de-leafing and sanitation to reduce pest refuge sites.

Balanced Banana Dataset/Banana Split Pee.description: Splitting of the banana peel occurs during the filling (bulking) stage. This is a physiological disorder, not a disease, caused primarily by sudden, large fluctuations in soil moisture (e.g., dry spell followed by heavy irrigation or rain) and sometimes poor nutritional balance (Calcium/Boron deficiency).

organic_solution.strategy: Maintain highly consistent soil moisture and improve soil structure to buffer sudden changes.

products.name: Mulching
products.details: Use heavy organic mulch (e.g., banana trash) around the base of the plant to regulate soil temperature and conserve moisture.

products.name: Consistent Irrigation
products.details: Irrigate regularly and consistently, especially during the dry season and bunch filling, to avoid rapid swings in soil moisture.

chemical_solution.strategy: Ensure adequate levels of nutrients involved in cell wall strength (Calcium and Boron).

products.name: Calcium and Boron Foliar Spray
products.details: Apply foliar sprays of Calcium and Boron during the fruit development stage to improve peel elasticity and cell wall integrity.

products.name: High Potassium Fertilizer
products.details: Apply high-potassium fertilizer to ensure optimal fruit filling, but manage total fertilizer input carefully.

Balanced Banana Dataset/Banana Split Pee.pathogen_timeline: N/A. The split occurs when the internal pressure from fruit filling exceeds the peel's strength, triggered by sudden water uptake.
prevention_tips: Avoid heavy fertilization or irrigation immediately following a prolonged drought.
Ensure proper de-suckering to balance the plant's nutrient demands.

Balanced Banana Dataset/Banana Skipper D.description: The Skipper caterpillar is a major pest, characterized by rolling the banana leaf tightly into a tube and feeding from inside, causing long, parallel cuts and reduced leaf area. Severe infestation leads to ragged, non-functional leaves.

organic_solution.strategy: Manual destruction of the rolled-up nests and targeted bio-pesticides.

products.name: Manual Crushing/Removal
products.details: Walk through the plantation and manually crush the rolled-up leaf shelters (nests) containing the feeding larvae.

products.name: Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt)
products.details: Specific microbial pesticide (NC) applied to the leaves near the feeding sites, as it is non-toxic to natural enemies.

chemical_solution.strategy: Use targeted insecticides. Control is justified if the damage is severe, as the pest is often controlled by natural enemies.

products.name: Emamectin Benzoate
products.details: Highly effective non-systemic insecticide (Group 6) for caterpillar control. Target the unrolled, young feeding areas.

products.name: Lambda-Cyhalothrin (e.g., Attack-CS)
products.details: Fast-acting pyrethroid (Group 3A) for immediate knockdown of severe infestations.

Balanced Banana Dataset/Banana Skipper D.pathogen_timeline: Pest population increases during the growing season. Damage must be managed to protect the three youngest leaves, which are critical for bunch filling.
prevention_tips: Regularly scout for the rolled leaf nests and destroy them immediately.
Conserve natural enemies like parasitic wasps, which can provide excellent biological control.

Balanced Banana Dataset/Banana Fruit-Sca.description: Small, dark beetles that chew on the peel of young, developing fruit, causing deep, corky, black lesions or patches on the peel. This significantly reduces the fruit's market value, though the flesh remains edible.

organic_solution.strategy: Physical protection of the bunch and removal of adult beetles.

products.name: Bunch Bagging (Plastic/Nylon)
products.details: Cover the young fruit bunch immediately after the male bud is removed (de-budding) with a bag (often blue plastic) to provide a physical barrier.

products.name: Neem Oil / Botanical Insecticide
products.details: Apply botanical insecticides to the newly emerging bunch/young fingers to deter beetle feeding.

chemical_solution.strategy: Apply insecticides to the newly emerged bunch before the peel hardens, focusing on the area of the hands and fingers.

products.name: Deltamethrin or Cypermethrin
products.details: Pyrethroid insecticides (Group 3A) applied to the bunch and upper leaves during bunch emergence to kill adult beetles.

products.name: Carbaryl (e.g., Sevin)
products.details: Carbamate insecticide (Group 1A) historically used for banana fruit pest control (use per local regulation).

Balanced Banana Dataset/Banana Fruit-Sca.pathogen_timeline: Damage occurs during the few weeks after the bunch emerges (the young fruit stage). Once the peel hardens, the damage stops. Control is time-sensitive.
prevention_tips: Bag the fruit bunch immediately after de-budding to prevent the primary damage.
Avoid planting adjacent to weedy or grassy areas where adult beetles may hide.

Balanced Banana Dataset/Anthracnose.description: A fungal disease that is primarily a post-harvest rot. It causes black, sunken spots on the fruit peel, particularly at the stem and blossom ends, often activated when the fruit starts ripening. It is also called 'Tip Rot' or 'Crown Rot'.

organic_solution.strategy: Sanitation, field control of the fungus, and post-harvest heat treatment.

products.name: Copper Oxychloride (Preventative)
products.details: Apply copper-based fungicides (FRAC M1) to bunches in the field to reduce latent spore load on the fruit surface.

products.name: Hot Water Treatment (Post-Harvest)
products.details: Dip harvested hands/fingers in hot water for 5 minutes before packing to kill latent surface spores.

chemical_solution.strategy: Post-harvest dip in approved fungicides is the most effective control measure.

products.name: Thiabendazole (TBZ) or Imazalil
products.details: Apply post-harvest fungicide dip (Group 1 or 3) to the fruit crown to control crown rot and anthracnose.

products.name: Chlorothalonil (Field Spray)
products.details: Field application of this protectant (FRAC M05) reduces overall fungal spore load, limiting post-harvest issues.

Balanced Banana Dataset/Anthracnose.pathogen_timeline: Infection is latent (hidden) on the fruit surface in the field. Disease develops rapidly once the fruit starts ripening (e.g., during transit or storage).
prevention_tips: Bag the banana bunch in the field to prevent mechanical damage and exposure to spores.
Ensure gentle handling and packing to avoid crown injury (entry point for the fungus).
